text: In the beginning God made from nothing the heavens and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth was an empty waste and darkness was over the deep waters. And the Spirit of God was moving over the top of the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.
speaker: God

text: God saw that the light was good. He divided the light from the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God called the light day, and He called the darkness night. There was evening and there was morning, one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be an open space between the waters. Let it divide waters from waters.”
speaker: God

text: God made the open space, and divided the waters under the open space from the waters above the open space. And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God called the open space Heaven. There was evening and there was morning, the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters under the heavens be gathered into one place. Let the dry land be seen.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: Then God called the dry land Earth. He called the gathering of the waters Seas. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let plants grow from the earth, plants that have seeds. Let fruit trees grow on the earth that bring their kind of fruit with their own seeds.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: Plants grew out of the earth, giving their own kind of seeds. Trees grew with their fruit, and their kind of seeds. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was evening and there was morning, the third day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let there be lights in the open space of the heavens to divide day from night. Let them tell the days and years and times of the year.
speaker: God

text: Let them be lights in the open space of the heavens to give light on the earth.” And it was so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God made the two great lights, the brighter light to rule the day, and the smaller light to rule the night. He made the stars also.
speaker: Narrator

text: God put them in the open space of the heavens to give light on the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: to rule the day and the night. He divided the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was evening and there was morning, the fourth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the waters be full of living things. Let birds fly above the earth in the open space of the heavens.”
speaker: God

text: God made the big animals that live in the sea, and every living thing that moves through the waters by its kind, and every winged bird after its kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: God wanted good to come to them, saying, “Give birth to many. Grow in number. Fill the waters in the seas. Let birds grow in number on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: There was evening and there was morning, the fifth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let the earth bring into being living things after their kind: Cattle and things that move upon the ground, and wild animals of the earth after their kind.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: Then God made the wild animals of the earth after their kind, and the cattle after their kind, and every thing that moves upon the ground after its kind. And God saw that it was good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “Let Us make man like Us and let him be head over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every thing that moves on the ground.”
speaker: God

text: And God made man in His own likeness. In the likeness of God He made him. He made both male and female.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God wanted good to come to them, saying, “Give birth to many. Grow in number. Fill the earth and rule over it. Rule over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the sky, and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”
speaker: God

text: Then God said, “See, I have given you every plant that gives seeds that is on the earth, and every tree that has fruit that gives seeds. They will be food for you.
speaker: God

text: I have given every green plant for food to every animal of the earth, and to every bird of the sky, and to every thing that moves on the earth that has life.” And it was so.
speaker: God

text: God saw all that He had made and it was very good. There was evening and there was morning, the sixth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the heavens and the earth were completed, and all that is in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day God ended His work which He had done. And He rested on the seventh day from all His work which He had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God honored the seventh day and made it holy, because in it He rested from all His work which He had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the story of the heavens and the earth when they were made, in the day the Lord God made the earth and the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now no bush of the field was yet on the earth. And no plant of the field had started to grow. For the Lord God had not sent rain upon the earth. And there was no man to work the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a fog came from the earth and watered the whole top of the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God made man from the dust of the ground. And He breathed into his nose the breath of life. Man became a living being.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God planted a garden to the east in Eden. He put the man there whom He had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God made to grow out of the ground every tree that is pleasing to the eyes and good for food. And He made the tree of life grow in the center of the garden, and the tree of learning of good and bad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a river flowed out of Eden to water the garden. And from there it divided and became four rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the first is Pishon. It flows around the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gold of that land is good. Bdellium and onyx stone are there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the second river is Gihon. It flows around the whole land of Cush.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the third river is Tigris. It flows east of Assyria. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to work the ground and care for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God told the man, “You are free to eat from any tree of the garden.
speaker: God

text: But do not eat from the tree of learning of good and bad. For the day you eat from it you will die for sure.”
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord God said, “It is not good for man to be alone. I will make a helper that is right for him.”
speaker: God

text: Out of the ground the Lord God made every animal of the field and every bird of the sky. He brought them to the man to find out what he would call them. And whatever the man called a living thing, that was its name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam gave names to all the cattle, and to the birds of the sky, and to every animal of the field. But there was no helper found that was right for Adam.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord God put the man to sleep as if he were dead. And while he was sleeping, He took one of the bones from his side and closed up the place with flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God made woman from the bone which He had taken from the man. And He brought her to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said, “This is now bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh. She will be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason a man will leave his father and his mother, and will be joined to his wife. And they will become one flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man and his wife were both without clothes and were not ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the snake was more able to fool others than any animal of the field which the Lord God had made. He said to the woman, “Did God say that you should not eat from any tree in the garden?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman said to the snake, “We may eat the fruit of the trees of the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from the tree which is in the center of the garden, God has said, ‘Do not eat from it or touch it, or you will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The snake said to the woman, “No, you for sure will not die!
speaker: Narrator

text: For God knows that when you eat from it, your eyes will be opened and you will be like God, knowing good and bad.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman saw that the tree was good for food, and pleasing to the eyes, and could fill the desire of making one wise. So she took of its fruit and ate. She also gave some to her husband, and he ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they knew they were without clothes. So they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they heard the sound of the Lord God walking in the garden in the evening. The man and his wife hid themselves from the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord God called to the man. He said to him, “Where are you?”
speaker: God

text: And the man said, “I heard the sound of You in the garden. I was afraid because I was without clothes. So I hid myself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God said, “Who told you that you were without clothes? Have you eaten from the tree of which I told you not to eat?”
speaker: God

text: The man said, “The woman whom You gave to be with me, she gave me fruit of the tree, and I ate.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God said to the woman, “What is this you have done?” And the woman said, “The snake fooled me, and I ate.”
speaker: God

text: Then the Lord God said to the snake, “Because you have done this, you will be hated and will suffer more than all cattle, and more than every animal of the field. You will go on your stomach and you will eat dust all the days of your life.
speaker: God

text: And I will make you and the woman hate each other, and your seed and her seed will hate each other. He will crush your head, and you will crush his heel.”
speaker: God

text: To the woman He said, “I will make your pain much worse in giving birth. You will give birth to children in pain. Yet your desire will be for your husband, and he will rule over you.”
speaker: God

text: Then He said to Adam, “Because you have listened to the voice of your wife, and have eaten from the tree of which I told you, “Do not eat from it,” the ground is cursed because of you. By hard work you will eat food from it all the days of your life.
speaker: God

text: It will grow thorns and thistles for you. You will eat the plants of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat bread by the sweat of your face because of hard work, until you return to the ground, because you were taken from the ground. You are dust, and you will return to dust.”
speaker: God

text: The man called his wife’s name Eve, because she was the mother of all living.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord God made clothes of skins for Adam and his wife, and dressed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord God said, “See, the man has become like one of Us, knowing good and bad. Now then, he might put out his hand to take from the tree of life also, and eat and live forever.”
speaker: God

text: So the Lord God sent him out from the garden of Eden, to work the ground from which he was taken.
speaker: God

text: So He drove the man out. And He placed cherubim east of the garden of Eden with a sword of fire that turned every way. They kept watch over the path to the tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man lay with his wife Eve and she was going to have a child and she gave birth to Cain. She said, “I have given birth to a man with the help of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Next she gave birth to his brother Abel. Now Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was one who worked the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The day came when Cain brought a gift of the fruit of the ground to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abel brought a gift of the first-born of his flocks and of the fat parts. The Lord showed favor to Abel and his gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: But He had no respect for Cain and his gift. So Cain became very angry and his face became sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry? And why are you looking down?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not your face be happy if you do well? If you do not do well, sin is waiting to destroy you. Its desire is to rule over you, but you must rule over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain told this to his brother Abel. And when they were in the field, Cain stood up against his brother Abel and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?” And he said, “I do not know. Am I my brother’s keeper?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood is crying to Me from the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you are cursed because of the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you work the ground, it will no longer give its strength to you. You will always travel from place to place on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Cain said to the Lord, “I am being punished more than I can take!
speaker: Narrator

text: See, this day You have made me go away from the land. And I will be hidden from Your face. I will run away and move from place to place. And whoever finds me will kill me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to him, “Whoever kills Cain will be punished by Me seven times worse.” And the Lord put a mark on Cain so that any one who found him would not kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Cain went away from the face of the Lord, and stayed in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cain lay with his wife and she was going to have a child and she gave birth to Enoch. Cain built a city and gave it the name of Enoch, the name of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Irad was born to Enoch. And Irad became the father of Mehujael. Mehujael became the father of Methushael. And Methushael became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech took two wives for himself. The name of one was Adah. And the name of the other was Zillah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to Jabal. He was the father of those who live in tents and have cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brother’s name was Jubal. He was the father of all those who play the harp and the horn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zillah gave birth to Tubal-cain who made things from brass and iron. The sister of Tubal-cain was Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Lamech said to his wives, “Adah and Zillah, listen to my voice. Hear what I say, you wives of Lamech. For I have killed a man for hurting me, and a boy for hitting me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If those who hurt Cain are punished seven times worse, then those who hurt Lamech will be punished seventy-seven times worse.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Adam lay with his wife again, and she gave birth to a son and gave him the name Seth. For she said, “God has let me have another son in the place of Abel, for Cain killed him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A son was born to Seth also, and he gave him the name Enosh. Then men began to call upon the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the book of the children of Adam and of their children’s children. When God made man, He made him in the likeness of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made them male and female, and brought good to them. And He gave them the name Man when they were made.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Adam had lived 130 years, he gave birth to a son in his own likeness. And he gave him the name Seth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adam lived 800 years after he became the father of Seth. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Adam lived 930 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Seth had lived 105 years, he became the father of Enosh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seth lived 807 years after the birth of Enosh. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Seth lived 912 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enosh had lived ninety years, he became the father of Kenan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enosh lived 815 years after the birth of Kenan. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Enosh lived 905 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Kenan had lived seventy years, he became the father of Mahalalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan lived 840 years after the birth of Mahalalel. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Kenan lived 910 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Mahalalel had lived sixty-five years, he became the father of Jared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahalalel lived 830 years after the birth of Jared. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Mahalalel lived 895 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jared had lived 162 years, he became the father of Enoch.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jared lived 800 years after the birth of Enoch. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jared lived 962 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Enoch had lived sixty-five years, he became the father of Methuselah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God 300 years after the birth of Methuselah. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Enoch lived 365 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch walked with God, and he was seen no more, for God took him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he became the father of Lamech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Methuselah lived 782 years after the birth of Lamech. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Methuselah lived 969 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he became the father of a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave him the name Noah. He said, “This one will give us rest from our work, from the hard work of our hands because the ground was cursed by the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lamech lived 595 years after the birth of Noah. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lamech lived 777 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah had lived 500 years, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When men became many in number on the earth, and daughters were born to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of men were beautiful. And they took wives for themselves, whomever they chose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “My Spirit will not stay in man forever, for he is flesh. But yet he will live for 120 years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Very large men were on the earth in those days, and later also, when the sons of God lived with the daughters of men, who gave birth to their children. These were the powerful men of long ago, men of much strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord saw that man was very sinful on the earth. Every plan and thought of the heart of man was sinful always.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was sorry that He had made man on the earth. He had sorrow in His heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “I will destroy man whom I have made from the land, man and animals, things that move upon the earth and birds of the sky. For I am sorry that I have made them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Noah found favor in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the story of Noah and his family. Noah was right with God. He was without blame in his time. Noah walked with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah became the father of three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the earth was sinful in the eyes of God. The earth was filled with people hurting each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: God looked at the earth and saw how sinful it was. For all who lived on the earth had become sinful in their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah, “I have decided to make an end to all the people on the earth. They are the cause of very much trouble. See, I will destroy them as I destroy the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a large boat of gopher wood for yourself. Build rooms in the boat. And cover it inside and out with tar.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you are to make it: The boat is to be as long as 150 long steps, as wide as twenty-five long steps, and eight times taller than a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make a window for the boat, that goes down a cubit from the roof. Put a door in the side of the boat. And make it with first, second, and third floors.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I will bring a flood of water upon the earth, to destroy all flesh under heaven that has the breath of life. Everything on earth will be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will make My agreement with you. You will go into the large boat, you and your sons and your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to bring into the large boat two of every kind of living thing of all flesh, to keep them alive with you. They will be male and female.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two of all the kinds of birds, and animals, and every thing that moves on the ground are to be with you to keep them alive.
speaker: Narrator

text: And take with you every kind of food that is eaten, and store it. It will be food for you and for them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah did just what God told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Noah, “Go into the boat, you and all your family. For I have seen that you only are right and good at this time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take with you seven of every clean animal of each sex, and one of each sex of the animals that are unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: And take with you seven of every kind of bird of the sky of each sex, to keep their kind alive over all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In seven days I will send rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights. I will destroy from the land every living thing that I have made.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Noah did all that the Lord told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah was 600 years old when the flood of water came upon the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives all went into the large boat because of the water of the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Clean animals and animals that were unclean and birds and every thing that moved on the ground
speaker: Narrator

text: went into the large boat with Noah. They went two by two, male and female, just as God had told Noah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After seven days the waters of the flood came upon the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year 600 of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, all the wells of water under the earth broke open. The windows of the heavens were opened.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rain fell upon the earth for forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the very same day Noah and his sons, Shem and Ham and Japheth, and Noah’s wife and the three wives of his sons with them, all went into the large boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: With them went every kind of animal, and all the cattle, and every thing that moved on the earth, and every kind of bird.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went into the large boat with Noah, two of every living thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Male and female of all flesh went in as God had told Noah. Then the Lord shut him in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The flood came upon the earth for forty days. The water got deeper and raised up the large boat so that it was lifted above the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water was very deep upon the earth. And the boat stayed upon the top of the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water got higher and higher upon the earth until all the high mountains under heaven were covered.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the water went about four times taller than a man above the tops of the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: All flesh that moved on the earth was destroyed, birds and cattle and wild animals, and every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every thing that had the breath of life and lived on dry land died.
speaker: Narrator

text: God destroyed every living thing upon the land, from man to animals, from things that moved upon the ground to birds of the sky. They were destroyed from the earth. Only Noah was left, and those that were with him in the large boat.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the water covered the earth for 150 days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God remembered Noah and all the wild animals and all the cattle that were with him in the large boat. Then God made a wind blow over the earth until the water went down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also the wells of water under the earth and the windows of the heavens were shut. And it stopped raining.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water kept moving away from the earth. At the end of 150 days the water was less.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, the large boat came to rest on Mount Ararat.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water kept on going down until the tenth month. In the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains could be seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of forty days, Noah opened the window of the large boat which he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent out a raven, and it flew here and there until the water was dried up from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent out a dove, to see if the water was gone from the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the dove found no place to set her foot, so she returned to him in the boat. For the water was still over the earth. So Noah put out his hand and took her, and brought her into the boat with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He waited another seven days, and sent the dove from the boat again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The dove returned to him in the evening. In her mouth was an olive leaf that had just been picked. So Noah knew that the water had gone from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he waited another seven days, and sent out the dove. But she did not return to him again.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year 601, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the water was dried up from the earth. Then Noah took the covering off the large boat, and looked out and saw that the earth was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the ground was dry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go out of the boat, you and your wife and your sons and your sons’ wives with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring out with you every living thing of all flesh that is with you, birds and animals and everything that moves on the earth. So they may give birth and become many upon the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah went out with his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every animal, every bird, everything that moves on the earth, went out of the large boat by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah built an altar to the Lord. He took of every clean animal and every clean bird, and gave burnt gifts in worship on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord smelled a pleasing smell. And the Lord said to Himself, “I will never again curse the ground because of man. For the desire of man’s heart is sinful from when he is young. I will never again destroy every living thing as I have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the earth lasts, planting time and gathering time, cold and heat, summer and winter, and day and night will not end.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God made good come to Noah and his sons, and said to them, “Have many children, and cover the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every animal of the earth, every bird of the sky, everything that moves on the ground, and all the fish of the sea will be afraid of you. They are given into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every moving thing that lives will be food for you. I give all to you as I gave you the green plants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not eat meat with blood in it because that is its life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For sure, I will take the life of every animal and every person for taking a life. I will punish every man’s brother for taking the life of man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever takes the life of a man will have his life taken. For God made man to be like Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, have many children. Cover the earth with many people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Noah and his sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, I make My agreement with you, and with your children after you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with every living thing that is with you, the birds, the cattle, and every animal of the earth, of all that came out of the large boat, every living thing on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I make My agreement with you, that never again will all flesh be destroyed by the water of a flood. There will never again be a flood to destroy the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said, “This is something special to see for all time, because of the agreement that I am making between Me and you and every living thing that is with you:
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set My rain-bow in the cloud, and it will be something special to see because of an agreement between Me and the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I bring clouds over the earth and the rain-bow is seen in the clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember My agreement that is between Me and you and every living thing of all flesh. Never again will the water become a flood to destroy all flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the rain-bow is in the cloud, I will look upon it to remember the agreement that will last forever between God and every living thing of all flesh that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Noah, “This is the special thing to see because of the agreement I have made between Me and all flesh upon the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Noah who came out of the large boat were Shem, Ham and Japheth. Ham was the father of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: These three were the sons of Noah. And all the people of the earth came from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Noah became a farmer and planted a grape-field.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he drank of the wine, and drank too much, and lay without covering himself in his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ham, the father of Canaan, saw that his father was without clothes. And he told his two brothers outside.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Shem and Japheth took a coat and laid it upon their shoulders and walked in with their backs toward their father and covered him. Their faces were turned away, so that they did not see their father without clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Noah awoke from his wine, he knew what his youngest son had done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “May Canaan be cursed! He will be a servant of servants to his brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also said, “Honor and thanks be to the Lord, the God of Shem. Let Canaan be his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God make Japheth great. Let him live in the tents of Shem. And let Canaan be his servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Noah lived 950 years, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of Shem, Ham and Japheth, the sons of Noah, and of their families. Sons were born to them after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
speaker: Narrator

text: From these the people who live beside the sea spread out into their lands, each one by his language, family, and nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush became the father of Nimrod, who was the first on earth to become a powerful man.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a powerful animal-killer in the eyes of the Lord. So it is said, “Like Nimrod, a powerful animal-killer in the eyes of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The beginning of his nation was Babel, Erech, Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went into Assyria from the land, and built Nineveh, Rehoboth-Ir, Calah
speaker: Narrator

text: and Resen between Nineveh and Calah. That is the great city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mizraim became the father of Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusim, Casluhim (from which came the Philistines), and Caphtorim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan became the father of Sidon, his first-born, and Heth,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Jebusite, the Amorite, the Girgashite,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hivite, the Arkite, the Sinite,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Arvadite, the Zemarite, and the Hamathite. Later the Canaanite families spread out.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the land of the Canaanite was from Sidon toward Gerar as far as Gaza, then toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim as far as Lasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Ham, by their families, languages, lands and nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Children were born to Shem, the father of all the children of Eber, and the older brother of Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arpachshad became the father of Shelah. Shelah became the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber had two sons. The name of one was Peleg, for the earth was divided in his day. The name of his brother was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan became the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land where they lived was from Mesha toward Sephar to the hill country of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Shem, by their families, languages, lands and nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the sons of Noah. From these family groups, nations were spread over the earth after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the whole earth used the same language and the same words.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as men traveled in the east, they found a valley in the land of Shinar and made their home there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to one another, “Come, let us make blocks and burn them until they are hard.” They used blocks for stone, and tar to hold them together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said, “Come, let us build a city for ourselves, with a tower that touches the heavens. Let us make a name for ourselves, or else we may be sent everywhere over the whole earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord came down to see the city and the tower that the sons of men had built.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “See, they are one people, and they all have the same language. This is only the beginning of what they will do. Now all they plan to do will be possible for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let Us go down and mix up their language so they will not understand what each other says.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent them everywhere over the whole earth. And they stopped building the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the name of the city was Babel, because there the Lord mixed up the language of the whole earth. The Lord sent the people everywhere over the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children of Shem. When Shem had lived 100 years, he became the father of Arpachshad, two years after the flood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shem lived 500 years after the birth of Arpachshad. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arpachshad had lived thirty-five years, he became the father of Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Arpachshad lived 403 years after the birth of Shelah. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shelah had lived thirty years, he became the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelah lived 403 years after the birth of Eber. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Eber had lived thirty-four years, he became the father of Peleg.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber lived 430 years after the birth of Peleg. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Peleg had lived thirty years, he became the father of Reu.
speaker: Narrator

text: Peleg lived 209 years after the birth of Reu. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Reu had lived thirty-two years, he became the father of Serug.
speaker: Narrator

text: Reu lived 207 years after the birth of Serug. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Serug had lived thirty years, he became the father of Nahor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Serug lived 200 years after the birth of Nahor. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Nahor had lived twenty-nine years, he became the father of Terah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nahor lived 119 years after the birth of Terah. He had other sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Terah had lived seventy years, he became the father of Abram, Nahor and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the children of Terah. Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor and Haran. And Haran became the father of Lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Haran died with his father Terah beside him in the land of his birth, Ur of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram and Nahor both married. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai. The name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran. Haran was the father of Milcah and Iscah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarai could not give birth. She had no child.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah took his son Abram, and his grandson Lot, the son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law Sarai, the wife of his son Abram and they went together from Ur of the Chaldeans to the land of Canaan. But when they went as far as Haran, they made their home there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Terah lived 205 years, and he died in Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord said to Abram, “Leave your country, your family and your father’s house, and go to the land that I will show you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will make you a great nation. I will bring good to you. I will make your name great, so you will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring good to those who are good to you. And I will curse those who curse you. Good will come to all the families of the earth because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram left as the Lord told him to do, and Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he left Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram took his wife Sarai, and his brother’s son Lot, and all the things they had gathered, and the people who joined them in Haran. And they left to go to the land of Canaan. So they came to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram passed through the land as far as the oak of Moreh at Shechem. The Canaanite people were living in the land at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord showed Himself to Abram and said, “I will give this land to your children and to your children’s children.” So Abram built an altar there to the Lord Who had shown Himself to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went from there to the mountain east of Bethel. He put up his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the Lord and called upon the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram traveled on, still going toward the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no food in the land. So Abram went south to Egypt to stay there, because it was very hard to live in the land with no food.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he was about to go into Egypt, Abram said to his wife Sarai, “I know that you are a beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Egypt see you, they will say, ‘This is his wife.’ And they will kill me, but they will let you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say that you are my sister. Then it may go well with me because of you. And because of you they will not kill me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram came into Egypt, the men of Egypt saw that the woman was very beautiful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s rulers saw her and told Pharaoh of her beauty. So the woman was taken into Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh acted well toward Abram because of Sarai. He gave Abram sheep, cattle, male and female donkeys, and camels, and men and women servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord sent much sickness upon Pharaoh and his house because of Abram’s wife Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh called Abram and said, “What is this you have done to me? Why did you not tell me that she was your wife?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I took her for my wife? Now then, here is your wife.’ Take her and go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh told his men what to do with Abram. They led him away with his wife and all that belonged to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram left Egypt and went to the Negev, with his wife and all that belonged to him. And Lot went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abram was very rich in cattle, silver and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He traveled from the Negev as far as Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai,
speaker: Narrator

text: where he had made an altar. And there Abram called on the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Lot, who went with Abram, had flocks and cattle and tents of his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was not enough land to feed all the animals while they lived together. They owned so many things that they were not able to stay together.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was fighting between those who cared for Abram’s animals and those who cared for Lot’s animals. The Canaanite and the Perizzite were living in the land at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram said to Lot, “Let there be no fighting between you and me or between the men who take care of our animals, for we are brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not the whole land in front of you? Let each of us go a different way. If you go to the left, then I will go to the right. Or if you go to the right, then I will go to the left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot looked and saw that the Jordan valley was well watered everywhere like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt as you go to Zoar. (This was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot chose all the Jordan valley for himself. And as Lot traveled east, they went apart from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram made his home in the land of Canaan. Lot made his home in the cities of the valley and moved his tents as far as Sodom,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose men were sinful, sinning against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Abram, after Lot had left him, “Raise your eyes and look from where you are to the north and south and east and west.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will give all the land that you see to you and to your children and to your children’s children forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your family after you like the dust of the earth. So if anyone could number the dust of the earth, then he could number your children’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rise up and walk far and wide upon the land. For I will give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram moved his tent and came to live among the oaks of Mamre in Hebron. There he built an altar to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was in the days of Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of Goiim,
speaker: Narrator

text: that they made war against Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).
speaker: Narrator

text: All these joined together in the valley of Siddim (that is, the Salt Sea).
speaker: Narrator

text: They had been ruled by Chedorlaomer for twelve years. But in the thirteenth year they went against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and won a war against the Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim, the Zuzim in Ham, the Emim in Shavehkiriathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Horites in their Mount Seir as far as El-paran near the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned around and came to Enmishpat (that is, Kadesh). There they won a war against all the country of the Amalekites and the Amorites who lived in Hazazon-tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim and Bela (that is, Zoar) went out and joined in war against them in the valley of Siddim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fought against Chedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of Goiim, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar, four kings against five.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Siddim valley was full of deep holes with tar. The kings of Sodom and Gomorrah turned and ran, and some fell there. But the others ran away into the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those who won the war took all that belonged to Sodom and Gomorrah, and all their food, and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took Lot, the son of Abram’s brother, who lived in Sodom, and all that belonged to him, and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one who had run for his life came and told Abram the Hebrew. Abram was living by the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, brother of Eshcol and Aner, who were friends of Abram.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram heard that one of his family had been taken away, he led 318 men who had been born in his house and whom he had taught to fight. They went after them as far as Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram divided his army against them by night, he and his servants. They won the war against them, and followed them as far as Hobah, north of Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram returned with all the things they had taken. He also returned with his brother’s son Lot and all that belonged to him, and the women and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abram returned from destroying Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s valley).
speaker: Narrator

text: Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine. He was a religious leader of God Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Melchizedek honored Abram and said, “May good come to Abram from God Most High, Maker of heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honor and thanks be to God Most High, Who has given into your hand those who fought against you.” Then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of all he had taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me the people, but take the riches and food for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have promised the Lord God Most High, Maker of heaven and earth,
speaker: Narrator

text: that I will not take a piece of string or piece of leather or anything that is yours. Or else you might say, ‘I have made Abram rich.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take nothing but what the young men have eaten, and the share of the men who went with me. Let Aner, Eshcol and Mamre take their share.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After these things, the word of the Lord came to Abram in a special dream, saying, “Do not be afraid, Abram. I am your safe place. Your reward will be very great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram said, “O Lord God, what will You give me? For I have no child. And the one who is to receive what belongs to me is Eliezer of Damascus.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram said, “Because You have not given me a child, one born in my house will be given all I have.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to him, saying, “This man will not be given what is yours. But he who will come from your own body will be given what is yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took him outside and said, “Now look up into the heavens and add up the stars, if you are able to number them.” Then He said to him, “Your children and your children’s children will be as many as the stars.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram believed in the Lord, and that made him right with God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “I am the Lord Who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land for your own.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abram said, “O Lord God, how may I know that it will be mine?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to him, “Bring Me a three-year-old cow, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, a turtledove and a young pigeon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram brought all these to Him, and cut them in two. And he laid each half beside the other. But he did not cut the birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the meat-eating birds came down upon the dead animals, Abram made them go away.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun was going down, Abram went into a sleep as if he were dead. And much fear and darkness came upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Abram, “Know for sure that your children and those born after them will be strangers in a land that is not theirs. There they will be servants and suffer for 400 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will punish the nation they will serve. And later they will come out with many riches.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will live many years, die in peace and be buried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then your great great-grandchildren will return here. For the sins of the Amorite are not yet finished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun had gone down and it was very dark, a fire pot of smoke and a burning fire passed between these parts of animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made an agreement with Abram on that day. He said, “I have given this land to your children and to their children’s children, from the river of Egypt as far as the big Euphrates River,
speaker: Narrator

text: the land of the Kenite, the Kenizzite, the Kadmonite,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Rephaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Amorite, the Canaanite, the Girgashite and the Jebusite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abram’s wife Sarai had not given birth to any children. She had a woman servant from Egypt whose name was Hagar.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarai said to Abram, “Now see, the Lord has kept me from having children. Go in to the woman who serves me. It may be that I will get children through her.” Abram listened to what Sarai said.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abram’s wife Sarai took Hagar the Egyptian, who served her, and gave her to her husband Abram as his wife. That was after Abram had lived ten years in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went in to Hagar, and she was going to have a child. And when she saw that she was going to have a child, she began to hate Sarai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarai said to Abram, “May the wrong done to me be upon you. I gave the woman who served me into your arms. But when she saw that she was going to have a child, she began to hate me. May the Lord judge who is guilty or not between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abram said to Sarai, “See, the woman who serves you is in your power. Do what you want with her.” So Sarai made it hard for Hagar. And Hagar ran away from her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord found Hagar by a well of water in the desert on the way to Shur.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Hagar, you who serve Sarai, where have you come from and where are you going?” And she said, “I am running away from Sarai, the one I serve.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your boss. Put yourself under her power.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to her, “I will give you so many people in your family through the years that they will be too many to number.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord also said to her, “See, you are going to have a child. And you will give birth to a son. You will give him the name Ishmael, because the Lord has heard how you have suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be a wild donkey of a man. His hand will be against all people. And the hand of all people will be against him. He will live to the east of all his brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hagar gave this name to the Lord Who spoke to her, “You are a God Who sees.” For she said, “Have I even stayed alive here after seeing Him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the well was called Beer-lahai-roi. It is between Kadesh and Bered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hagar gave birth to Abram’s son. And Abram gave his son who was born of Hagar the name Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave birth to his son Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord came to him and said, “I am God All-powerful. Obey Me, and be without blame.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will keep My agreement between Me and you. I will give you many children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abram fell on his face. God said to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, My agreement is with you. You will be the father of many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: No more will your name be Abram. But your name will be Abraham. For I will make you the father of many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many will come from you. I will make nations of you. Kings will come from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make My agreement between Me and you and your children after you through their whole lives for all time. I will be God to you and to your children’s children after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give to you and your children after you the land in which you are a stranger, all the land of Canaan for yourselves forever. And I will be their God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “You must keep My agreement, you and your children after you for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is My agreement between Me and you and your children after you, which you must obey: Every man among you must have this religious act done.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this religious act the skin is cut off from the end of your sex part. This will be the special act of the agreement between Me and you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every male child among you who is eight days old must have this religious act done, through all time. The same must be done to all the men born in your house or bought with your money from any stranger, who is not one of your family.
speaker: Narrator

text: He that is born in your house and he that is bought with your money must have this religious act done. So will My agreement be marked in your flesh, an agreement that lasts forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man who has not had this religious act done, of cutting off his piece of skin, will be cut off from his people. He has broken My agreement.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, do not call her name Sarai. But Sarah will be her name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will bring good to her. I will give you a son by her. I will bring good to her. And she will be the mother of nations. Kings of many people will come from her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham fell on his face and laughed. He said to himself, “Will a child be born to a man who is 100 years old?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham said to God, “If only Ishmael might live before You!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said, “No, but your wife Sarah will give birth to your son. And you will give him the name Isaac. I will make My agreement with him and for his children after him, an agreement that will last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Ishmael, I have heard you. I will bring good to him. I will make him grow in number. He will be the father of twelve rulers. I will make him a great nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will make My agreement with Isaac, who will be born to Sarah at this time next year.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When He had finished talking with him, God went up from Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham took his son Ishmael, and all who were born in his house, and all who were bought with his money, and every man and boy who lived in his house. And he cut off their piece of skin that very day, as God had told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he had the religious act done of cutting off his piece of skin.
speaker: Narrator

text: His son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he had the religious act done of cutting off his piece of skin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham and his son Ishmael had this religious act done that very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the men of his house, who were born in the house or bought with money from a stranger, had this religious act done with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord showed Himself to Abraham by the oak trees of Mamre, as he sat at the tent door in the heat of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham looked up and saw three men standing in front of him. When he saw them, he ran from the tent door to meet them. He put his face to the ground
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “My lord, if I have found favor in your eyes, please do not pass by your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let us have a little water brought to wash your feet. Rest yourselves under the tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will get a piece of bread so you may eat and get strength. After that you may go on your way, since you have come to your servant.”
The men said, “Do as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham ran into the tent to Sarah, and said, “Hurry and get three pails of fine flour, mix it well, and make bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham ran to the cattle and took out a young and good calf. He gave it to the servant to make it ready in a hurry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took milk and cheese and the meat which he had made ready, and set it in front of them. He stood by them under the tree while they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they said to him, “Where is your wife Sarah?” And he said, “There in the tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “I will be sure to return to you at this time next year. And your wife Sarah will have a son.” Sarah was listening at the tent door behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old. They had lived many years. The way of women had stopped for Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarah laughed to herself, saying, “Will I have this joy after my husband and I have grown old?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘How can I give birth to a child when I am so old?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anything too hard for the Lord? I will return to you at this time next year, and Sarah will have a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarah said, “I did not laugh,” because she was afraid. And He said, “No, but you did laugh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men got up from there and looked down toward Sodom. Abraham went with them to send them on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “Should I hide from Abraham what I am about to do,
speaker: Narrator

text: since Abraham will become a great and powerful nation, because good will come to all the nations of the earth through him?
speaker: Narrator

text: For I have chosen him, so that he may teach his children and the sons of his house after him to keep the way of the Lord by doing what is right and fair. So the Lord may bring to Abraham what He has promised him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said, “The cry against Sodom and Gomorrah is loud. Their sin is very bad.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will now go down and see if they have done as much wrong as the cry against them has told Me they have. And if not, I will know.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men turned away from there and went toward Sodom. But Abraham still stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham came near and said, “Will You destroy the good also, with the bad?
speaker: Narrator

text: What if there are fifty good people within the city? Will You destroy the place and not save it because of the fifty good people in it?
speaker: Narrator

text: May You never do such a thing as to destroy the good with the bad! May the good never be punished like the bad! You would never do such a thing! Will not the Judge of all the earth do what is right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said, “If I find fifty good people in the city of Sodom, I will save the whole place because of them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “Now see, I have taken upon myself to speak to the Lord, I who am only dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: What if five of the fifty good people are not so good. Will You destroy the whole city because of five?” The Lord said, “I will not destroy it if I find forty-five good people there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham spoke to Him again and said, “What if only forty are found there?” The Lord said, “I will not destroy it if there are forty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham said, “O may the Lord not be angry, and I will speak. What if only thirty are found there?” The Lord said, “I will not do it if I find thirty there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “Now see, I have taken upon myself to speak to the Lord. What if twenty are found there?” The Lord said, “I will not destroy it because of the twenty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham said, “O may the Lord not be angry. And I may speak once more. What if ten are found there?” The Lord said, “I will not destroy it because of the ten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord went on His way when He finished speaking with Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two angels came to Sodom in the evening. Lot was sitting in the gate of Sodom. When Lot saw them, he got up to meet them. He put his face to the ground
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “My lords, come into the house of your servant. Stay the night, and wash your feet. Then you may rise early and go on your way.” But they said, “No, we will stay the night in the street.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he begged them, so they turned aside with him and went into his house. And he made a supper for them. He made bread without yeast, and they ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before they went to bed, all the men of the city of Sodom both young and old gathered around the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They called to Lot, saying, “Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so we may lie with them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Lot went out the door to the men, and shut the door behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “My brothers, please do not be so sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have two daughters who have never had a man. Let me bring them out to you. And do to them whatever you want. But do nothing to these men, for they have come to be safe under my roof.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “Get out of our way. This man came to live here from another land. And already he acts like a judge. Now we will do worse things to you than to them.” So they pushed hard against Lot and almost broke down the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the two men put out their hands and brought Lot into the house with them, and shut the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they blinded the men who were at the door of the house, both small and big. So the men became tired trying to find the door.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two men asked Lot, “Do you have any others here? Sons-in-law, your sons, your daughters, anyone you have in the city, bring them out of this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are about to destroy this place. Because the cry against its people has become so loud to the Lord that the Lord has sent us to destroy it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Lot went out to speak to his sons-in-law who were to marry his daughters. He said, “Get up! Get out of this place! For the Lord will destroy the city!” But his sons-in-law thought he was only joking.
speaker: Narrator

text: When morning came, the angels told Lot to hurry. They said, “Get up. Take your wife and your two daughters who are here. Or else you will be destroyed when the city is punished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot was slow to move. So the men took him, his wife and two daughters by the hand and brought them out of the city. For the Lord had loving-pity for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had brought them out of the city, one of them said, “Run for your life! Do not look behind you. Do not stop until you are out of the valley. Run to the mountains or else you will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot said to them, “O, no, my lords!
speaker: Narrator

text: See, your servant has found favor in your eyes. You have shown me great kindness in what you have done for me by saving my life. But I cannot run to the mountains. For I will run into danger and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, this town is near enough to run to, and it is small. Let me run there (is it not small?) and my life will be saved.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel said to him, “See, I am doing what you ask. I will not destroy this town that you have spoken about.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry and run there. For I cannot do anything until you get there.” So the name given to the town was Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun had moved over the earth when Lot came to Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord poured fire from the heavens upon Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He destroyed those cities, and all the valley, and all the people of the cities, and what grew on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Lot’s wife behind him turned and looked toward the cities. And she was changed into salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham went early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and toward all the land of the valley. And he saw the smoke of the land going up like the smoke from a place where there is much fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when God destroyed the cities of the valley, He remembered Abraham. He sent Lot out of the center of the danger, when He destroyed the cities where Lot lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Lot went up from Zoar with his two daughters, and lived in the mountains for he was afraid to stay in Zoar. He lived in a cave in the side of a mountain with his two daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the first-born daughter said to the younger one, “Our father is old. And there is not a man on earth to marry us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us make our father drink wine. Let us lie with him, so we may keep our family through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night. And the first-born went in and lay with her father. He did not know when she lay down or when she got up.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day, the first-born said to the younger, “See, I lay with my father last night. Let us make him drink wine tonight also, then you go in and lie with him. And we may keep our family through our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made their father drink wine that night also, then the younger daughter went and lay with him. He did not know when she lay down or when she got up.
speaker: Narrator

text: So both the daughters of Lot were going to have a child by their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first-born daughter gave birth to a son, and gave him the name Moab. He is the father of the Moabites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The younger daughter gave birth to a son also. She gave him the name Benammi. He is the father of the Ammonites to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham traveled from there to the land of the Negev, and made his home between Kadesh and Shur. Then he lived for a time in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said about his wife Sarah, “She is my sister.” So Abimelech king of Gerar sent for Sarah and took her for his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Abimelech in a dream of the night, and said, “See, you are a dead man because of the woman you have taken. For she is already married.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abimelech had not come near her. He said, “Lord, will You destroy a nation who is without blame?
speaker: Narrator

text: Did the man not tell me, ‘She is my sister’? And she, even she herself said, ‘He is my brother.’ I have done this with a heart of honor and with hands that are not guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to him in the dream, “Yes, I know that you have done this with a heart of honor. And I kept you from sinning against Me. I did not let you touch her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now return the man’s wife. For he is one who speaks for Me. Then he will pray for you, and you will live. But if you do not return her, know that you and all who are yours will die for sure.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech got up early in the morning. He called all his servants and told them all these things. And the men were very much afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech called Abraham and said, “What have you done to us? What wrong have I done to you, that made you bring a great sin upon me and my nation? You have done to me what should not have been done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said to Abraham, “What made you do such a thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “I did it because I thought there was no fear of God in this place. I thought they would kill me because of my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it is true she is my sister. She is the daughter of my father, but not of my mother. And she became my wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When God made me go from my father’s house, I said to Sarah, ‘This is the kindness you must show me. Everywhere we go, say of me, “He is my brother.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech gave to Abraham sheep and cattle, and men and women servants. And he returned his wife Sarah to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “See, my land is in front of you. Make your home any place you want.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Sarah, “See, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver. It is to pay you for all that has happened. Your honor is made right in the eyes of all men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham prayed to God. And God healed Abimelech, his wife and the women who served him, so that they gave birth to children.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had stopped all births in the house of Abimelech because of Abraham’s wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord visited Sarah as He had said and did for her as He had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah was able to have a child and she gave birth to a son when Abraham was very old. He was born at the time the Lord said it would happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave the name Isaac to his son who was born to him by Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham did the religious act of the Jews on Isaac when he was eight days old, as God had told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was one hundred years old when Isaac was born.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Sarah said, “God has made me laugh. All who hear will laugh with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet when he is so old I have given him a son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the child grew old enough to stop nursing, Abraham made a special supper on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian make fun of Isaac. Abraham was the father of Hagar’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Sarah said to Abraham, “Put this woman servant and her son out of your home. The son of this woman servant will never get any of the riches of the family as will my son Isaac.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the thing brought much sorrow to Abraham because of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to Abraham, “Do not be full of sorrow because of the boy and the woman who serves you. Listen to whatever Sarah tells you. For your children and all their children’s children after you will be given a name through Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will also make a nation of the son of the woman who serves you, because he is your son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham got up early in the morning. He took bread and a leather bag of water, and gave it to Hagar, putting it on her shoulder. He gave her the boy, and sent her away. She left, and went from place to place in the desert in Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the water was gone, she put the boy under one of the bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she sat down as far away from him as an arrow flies. For she said, “Do not let me see the boy die.” As she sat there, she cried a loud cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God heard the voice of the boy. Then the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven, and said, “Why are you so troubled, Hagar? Do not be afraid. For God has heard the cry of the boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up. Lift up the boy and hold him by the hand. For I will make a great nation of him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God opened Hagar’s eyes. And she saw a well of water. She went and filled the leather bag with water and gave the boy a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was with the boy and he grew. He lived in the desert, and became very good in using the bow.
speaker: Narrator

text: While living in the desert of Paran, his mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, Abimelech with Phicol, the head of his army, said to Abraham, “God is with you in all that you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So promise me here by God that you will not work against me, or my son, or any children after me. I have shown you kindness. So return kindness to me and to the land where you have come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “I promise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abraham spoke to Abimelech about a well of water that the servants of Abimelech had taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “I do not know who did this. You never told me. And I did not hear about it until today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham took sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech. Then the two men made an agreement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham set seven lambs of the flock away from the others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said to Abraham, “What do these seven lambs that you have set apart mean?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “Take these seven lambs from me as an agreement to me that I dug this well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gave that place the name Beersheba because both of them made a promise there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made an agreement at Beersheba. Then Abimelech and Phicol, the head of his army, returned to the land of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham planted a tree at Beersheba. He called there on the name of the Lord, the God Who lives forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines for many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later God tested Abraham, and said to him, “Abraham!” Abraham said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said, “Take now your son, your only son, Isaac, whom you love. And go to the land of Moriah. Give him as a burnt gift on the altar in worship, on one of the mountains I will show you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham got up early in the morning and got his donkey ready. He took two of his young men with him and his son Isaac. He cut wood for the burnt gift. And he went to the place where God told him to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham looked up on the third day and saw the place far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey. I and the boy will go to that place and worship, and return to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt gift and had Isaac carry it. He took in his hand the fire and the knife. And the two of them walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said to Abraham, “My father!” Abraham answered, “Here I am, my son.” Isaac said, “See, here is the fire and the wood. But where is the lamb for the burnt gift?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said, “God will have for Himself a lamb ready for the burnt gift, my son.” So the two of them walked on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to the place that God told them about. Abraham built the altar there, and set the wood in place. Then he tied rope around his son Isaac, and laid him upon the wood on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abraham put out his hand and took the knife to kill his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord called to him from heaven, and said, “Abraham! Abraham!” And Abraham said, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said, “Do not put out your hand against the boy. Do nothing to him. For now I know that you fear God. You have not kept from Me your son, your only son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham looked and saw a ram behind him, with his horns caught in the bushes. Abraham went and took the ram, and gave him as a burnt gift instead of his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave that place the name “The Lord will give us what we need.” And it is said to this day, “On the mountain of the Lord it will be given.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord called to Abraham from heaven a second time.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “I have promised by Myself, says the Lord, because you have done this and have not kept from Me your son, your only son,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring good to you. I will add many to the number of your children and all who come after them, like the stars of the heavens and the sand beside the sea. They will take over the cities of those who hate them.
speaker: Narrator
