text: Good will come to all the nations of the earth by your children and their children’s children. Because you have obeyed My voice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham returned to his young men. And they got up and went with him to Beersheba. Abraham made his home there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later it was told to Abraham, “Milcah also has given birth to the children of your brother Nahor:
speaker: Narrator

text: Uz the first-born, Buz his brother, Kemuel the father of Aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. Milcah gave birth to these eight by Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Reumah, the woman he kept who acted as his wife, gave birth to Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sarah lived 127 years. These were the years of Sarah’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sarah died in Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan. And Abraham had sorrow for Sarah and cried for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham got up from beside his dead wife, and said to the sons of Heth,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am a stranger living among you for a time. Give me some of your land so I may bury my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Heth answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen to us, my lord. You are a powerful ruler among us. Bury your wife in the best of our graves. None of us will keep his grave from you for burying your wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abraham stood up and bowed to the people of the land, the sons of Heth.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “If you are willing to have me bury my wife, hear me, and ask Zohar’s son Ephron for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask him to give me the grave of Machpelah which he has at the other side of his field. Let him give it to me for the full price in front of you, for a place to bury my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephron was sitting among the sons of Heth. So Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham so what he said could be heard by the sons of Heth and all who came in through the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “No, my lord. Listen to me. I give you the field. And I give you the grave that is in it. I give it to you in front of the sons of my people. Bury your wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham bowed to the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Ephron so that all the people of the land heard it, “Listen to me if you will. I will give you the price of the field. Receive it from me, that I may bury my wife there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephron answered Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: “My lord, listen to me. The land is worth four hundred pieces of silver. What is that between me and you? So bury your wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham listened to Ephron. And Abraham weighed for Ephron the silver which he had said and was heard by the sons of Heth to be the price, four hundred pieces of silver. He weighed it in the same way those who buy and sell weighed it at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ephron’s field in Machpelah east of Mamre, the field and grave that was in it, and all the trees within the sides of the field, were handed over
speaker: Narrator

text: to Abraham for his own. It was handed over in front of the sons of Heth and all who came in through the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the grave of the field of Machpelah east of Mamre (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The field and the grave in it were handed over to Abraham by the sons of Heth for a place to bury his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abraham was old. He had lived many years. And the Lord had brought good to Abraham in every way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to the oldest servant in his house and the one who took care of all that he owned, “Place your hand under my hip,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will have you promise by the Lord, the God of heaven and earth. Promise that you will not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, who live around me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But go to my country and to those of my family. Take a wife for my son Isaac from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant said to Abraham, “What if the woman will not be willing to follow me to this land? Should I take your son to the land you came from?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham said to him, “Make sure that you do not take my son there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord, the God of heaven, Who took me from my father’s house and from the land of my birth, spoke to me and promised me. He said, ‘I will give this land to your children and to their children’s children.’ He will send His angel in front of you. And you will take a wife for my son from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the woman is not willing to follow you, then you will be free from this promise to me. Only do not take my son there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant placed his hand under the hip of Abraham, and he promised to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant took ten of Abraham’s camels and left. He took with him all kinds of gifts from Abraham. Then he went to the city of Nahor in Mesopotamia.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the camels get down on their knees outside the city by the well of water in the evening. It was the time when women go out to get water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “O Lord, the God of my boss Abraham, let all go well for me today. Show loving-kindness to my boss Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I am standing here by the well of water. And the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to get water.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I say to a girl, ‘Let down your jar so that I may drink,’ and she answers, ‘Drink, and I will give water to your camels also,’ let her be the one whom You have chosen for your servant Isaac. I will know by this that You have shown loving-kindness to my boss.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Before he had finished speaking, Rebekah came out, the daughter of Bethuel, the son of Milcah and Nahor, the brother of Abraham. She had a jar on her shoulder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The girl was very beautiful and had never lain with a man. She went down to the well, filled her jar and came up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the servant ran to meet her. He said, “Let me drink a little water from your jar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Drink, my lord.” And she was quick to lift her jar to her hand and give him a drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she had finished giving him a drink, she said, “I will get water for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She was quick to empty her jar into the animals’ drinking place. Then she ran to the well for more water, and got enough for all his camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man was quiet and watched her, waiting to know if the Lord had made all go well or not during his visit.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the camels had finished drinking, the man took a heavy gold ring and two heavy gold objects to wear on her arms.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Whose daughter are you? Tell me, is there a place for us to stay in your father’s house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son of Milcah and Nahor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She also said, “We have both enough straw and food, and a place to stay.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man bowed low and worshiped the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Honor and thanks be to the Lord, the God of my boss Abraham. He has not kept His loving-kindness and His truth from my boss. He has led me in the way to the house of my boss’s brothers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the girl ran and told about all this to those in her mother’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban. And Laban ran outside to the man at the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw the gold objects his sister was wearing, and heard his sister Rebekah saying, “This is what the man said to me,” he went to the man. He saw him standing by the camels at the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “Come in, you who receive good from the Lord! Why do you stand outside? I have made the house ready, and a place for the camels.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man came into the house. Laban took the load off the camels, and gave them straw and food. He got water to wash the feet of Abraham’s servant and the feet of the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then food was set in front of the man to eat. But he said, “I will not eat until I have told you why I came here.” Laban said, “Tell it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said, “I am Abraham’s servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord has brought much good to my boss. He has become rich. The Lord has given him flocks and cattle, silver and gold, men and women servants, and camels and donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: My boss’s wife Sarah gave birth to my boss’s son when she was very old. And he has given him all he has.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My boss made me promise, saying, ‘Do not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I live.
speaker: Narrator

text: But go to my father’s house, to those of my family, and take a wife for my son there.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to my owner, ‘What if the woman will not follow me?’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘The Lord, Whom I have always obeyed, will send His angel with you to make all go well during your visit there. You will take a wife for my son from those of my family and from my father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will be free from your promise to me. When you come to those of my family, and if they do not give her to you, then you will be free from your promise to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I came to the well today. I said, ‘O Lord, the God of my boss Abraham, may all go well during my visit here.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I am standing by the well of water. If I say to the girl who comes out for water, “Let me drink a little water from your jar,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and she says, “You drink, and I will get water for your camels also,” then let her be the woman whom the Lord has chosen for my boss’s son.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Before I had finished speaking in my heart, Rebekah came out with her jar on her shoulder. She went down to the well and got water. I asked her, ‘Let me drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And she was quick to take down her jar from her shoulder. She said, ‘Drink, and I will give water to your camels also.’ So I drank and she gave water to the camels also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah and Nahor.’ And I put the gold objects on her nose and arms.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I bowed low and worshiped the Lord. I gave honor and thanks to the Lord, the God of my boss Abraham. For He had led me in the right way to take the daughter of my boss’s brother for his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now if you will show kindness and be true to my boss, tell me. And if not, tell me so I may know which way to turn.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban and Bethuel answered, “This thing comes from the Lord. We cannot speak for or against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, Rebekah is in front of you. Take her and go. Let her be the wife of your boss’s son, as the Lord has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he put his face to the ground before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out things made of silver and gold, and clothes, and gave them to Rebekah. He gave things of much worth to her brother and mother also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he and the men with him ate and drank and stayed the night there. When they got up in the morning, he said, “Send me away to my boss.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But her brother and her mother said, “Let the girl stay with us a few days, at least ten. Then she may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said to them, “Do not make me stay any more days, since the Lord has made my way go well. Send me away so I may go to my boss.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We will call the girl and ask her what she wants to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They called Rebekah and asked her, “Will you go with this man?” And she said, “I will go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent away their sister Rebekah and her nurse. They went with Abraham’s servant and the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They prayed that good would come to Rebekah, and said to her, “You are our sister. May you become the mother of millions. May your children and all their children’s children after them take over the cities of those who hate them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah and her servants got up on the camels and followed the man. So the servant of Abraham took Rebekah and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac had come from Beerlahairoi, and was living in the Negev.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac had gone out to pray in the field in the evening. He looked up and saw that camels were coming.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rebekah looked up and saw Isaac. She got off the camel
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to Abraham’s servant, “Who is that man walking in the field to meet us?” Abraham’s servant said, “He is my boss.” So she took a cloth and covered her face.
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant told Isaac all the things he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent, and she became his wife. And he loved her. So Isaac found comfort after his mother’s death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham took another wife whose name was Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave birth to his sons, Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokshan became the father of Sheba and Dedan. The sons of Dedan were Asshurim, Letushim, and Leummim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were the sons of Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham gave all he had to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while he was still living, Abraham gave gifts to the sons of the women he kept who acted as his wives. And he sent them to the land of the East, away from his son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham lived 175 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abraham breathed his last and died, after living a long and full life of many good years, and was buried with his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the grave of Machpelah, in the field of Ephron the son of Zohar the Hittite, east of Mamre.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the field that Abraham bought from the sons of Heth. Abraham was buried there with his wife Sarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the death of Abraham, God brought good to his son Isaac. And Isaac lived at Beerlahairoi.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children and their children’s children of Abraham’s son Ishmael, who was born to Abraham and Hagar, who was Sarah’s woman servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, the names of the first-born to the last: Nebaioth, Ishmael’s first-born, then Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Ishmael and these are their names, by their towns and by their groups of tents, twelve rulers and their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmael lived 137 years. Then he breathed his last and died, and was buried with his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: His people lived from Havilah as far as Shur, east of Egypt on the way toward Assyria. He lived away from all his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children and their children’s children of Abraham’s son Isaac. Abraham was the father of Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac was forty years old when he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Syrian of Paddan-aram, and the sister of Laban the Syrian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac prayed to the Lord for his wife, because she could not give birth and the Lord answered him. Rebekah was able to give birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the babies within her fought together. And she said, “If this is so, why am I like this?” She went to ask the Lord why.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to her, “Two nations are within you. Two peoples will be divided from your body. One will be stronger than the other. And the older will serve the younger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the day came for her to give birth, there were two babies to be born.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first to come out was red and he had hair all over his body. They gave him the name of Esau.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the brother was born. His hand was holding Esau’s heel. So he was given the name of Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when Rebekah gave birth to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the boys grew older, Esau became a good hunter, a man of the field. But Jacob was a man of peace, living in tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac showed favor to Esau, because he liked to eat the meat of the animals Esau killed. But Rebekah showed favor to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Jacob was getting food ready one day, Esau came in from the field and was very hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said to Jacob, “Let me eat some of that red meat, for I am very hungry.” That is why his name was called Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said, “First, sell me your birth-right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “See, I am about to die. So what good is my birth-right to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “First give me your promise.” So Esau promised, and sold his birth-right to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob gave Esau bread and vegetables, and Esau ate and drank. Then Esau stood up and went on his way. So Esau hated his birth-right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was another time when there was no food in the land, after the time of no food in the days of Abraham. So Isaac went to Gerar, to Abimelech king of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord showed Himself to Isaac, and said, “Do not go to Egypt. Stay in the land I will tell you about.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live in this land and I will be with you and bring good to you. For I will give all these lands to you and your children. I will keep the promise I made to your father Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your children and all your children’s children as many as the stars of heaven. I will give these lands to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Abraham obeyed Me. He did what I told him to do. He kept My Word and My Law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac stayed in Gerar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the place asked him about his wife, he said, “She is my sister.” He was afraid to say, “She is my wife,” because he thought to himself, “The men of this place might kill me because of Rebekah, for she is beautiful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac had been there a long time, Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out of the window. And he saw Isaac loving his wife Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech called Isaac and said, “See, she is your wife! How could you say, ‘She is my sister’?” Isaac said to him, “Because I thought I would die because of her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the men might have lain with your wife. And you would have brought guilt upon us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech told all the people, “Whoever touches this man or his wife will be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac planted seeds in that land. And he gathered in the same year a hundred times as much as he had planted. The Lord brought good to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac became rich and kept getting richer until he became a great man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he had flocks and many cattle and many people working in his house. The Philistines became jealous of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They filled all the wells with dirt that his father’s servants had dug in the days of his father Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech said to Isaac, “Go away from us. For you are too powerful for us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac left that place. He put up his tents in the valley of Gerar, and lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaac dug again the wells of water that had been dug in the days of his father Abraham. For the Philistines had closed them up after the death of Abraham. And he gave them the same names that his father had given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and found a well of flowing water there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who took care of the cattle of Gerar argued with the men who took care of Isaac’s cattle. They said, “The water belongs to us!” So Isaac gave the well the name Esek, because they argued with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his servants dug another well. And they argued about it also. So he gave it the name Sitnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He moved away from there and dug another well. And they did not argue about it. So he gave it the name Rehoboth. For he said, “Now the Lord has made a large place for us. We will grow much in this land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went from there to Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord showed Himself to Isaac that same night, and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Do not be afraid, for I am with you. I will bring good to you, and add many to the number of your children and their children’s children, because of My servant Abraham.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac built an altar there. And he called upon the name of the Lord. He put up his tent there. And there Isaac’s servants dug a well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech came to him from Gerar, with his friend Ahuzzath, and Phicol, the leader of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me when you hate me and have sent me away from you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “It is easy for us to see that the Lord is with you. So we said, ‘Let there now be a promise between us, between you and us. Let us make an agreement with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: that you will not hurt us in any way. For we have not touched you, and have done nothing to you but good. We sent you away in peace. And you now have the Lord’s favor.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac made a special supper for them, and they ate and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: They got up early in the morning and made promises to each other. Then Isaac sent them away, and they left him in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug. They said to him, “We have found water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gave the well the name Shibah. So the name of the city is Beersheba to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they made life full of sorrow for Isaac and Rebekah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac was now old, and had become blind. He called to his older son Esau, saying, “My son.” And Esau answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said, “See, I am old. I do not know when I will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your bow and arrows, and go out to the field to get meat for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get some food ready for me that I love. Bring it to me to eat, so that before I die I will pray that good will come to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rebekah was listening while Isaac spoke to his son Esau. So when Esau went to the field to hunt for meat to bring home,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “I heard your father talking to your brother Esau. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ’Bring me some meat. Make good-tasting food for me to eat. And before I die I will pray to the Lord for good to come to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, my son, listen to what I tell you to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the flock and bring me two fat young goats. I will cook them into good-tasting food, just what your father loves to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will take it to your father for him to eat. So before he dies he will pray for good to come to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “But my brother Esau has much hair. And my skin is smooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: If my father touches me, he will think of me as one trying to fool him. Then he will bring a curse upon me instead of good.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His mother said to him, “The curse will come upon me instead of you, my son. You do what I say, and go get them for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went and got them, and brought them to his mother. And his mother made good-tasting food, just what his father loved to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah took the best clothes that belonged to her older son Esau, that were with her in the house. And she put them on her younger son Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: She put the skins of the young goats on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she gave her son Jacob the bread and the good-tasting food she had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went to his father and said, “My father.” Isaac said, “Here I am. Who are you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau, your first-born. I have done as you told me. Sit up and eat the meat I brought, so you will pray that good will come to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Isaac said to his son, “How have you found it so fast, my son?” And Jacob said, “Because the Lord your God made it happen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know for sure if you are my son Esau or not.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob came near his father Isaac. Isaac touched him, and said, “The voice is Jacob’s voice. But the hands are Esau’s hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not know who he was, because his hands were covered with hair like his brother Esau’s hands. So Isaac prayed that good would come to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac said, “Is it true that you are my son Esau?” Jacob answered, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac said, “Bring it to me so I may eat the meat my son has made ready. And I will pray that good will come to you.” He brought it to him, and he ate. He brought him wine also, and he drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come near and kiss me, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob came near and kissed him. When Isaac smelled his clothes, he prayed that good would come to him. He said, “The smell of my son is like the smell of a field that has received good from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God give you from heaven water on the grass in the early morning, and the riches of the earth, and more than enough grain and new wine.
speaker: Narrator

text: May nations serve you, and the people bow down in front of you. Be the ruler of your brothers. May your mother’s sons bow down in front of you. Cursed be those who curse you, and may good come to those who honor you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Isaac had finished praying that good would come to Jacob, Jacob left his father Isaac. Just then his brother Esau came in from hunting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau made good-tasting food and brought it to his father, and said, “Sit up, my father, and eat the meat your son has made ready, so you will pray that good will come to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father Isaac said to him, “Who are you?” He answered, “I am your son, your first-born, Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac shook all over, and he said, “Who was it then who killed an animal and brought meat to me? I ate all of it before you came! And I prayed that good would come to him! Yes, and good will come to him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard what his father said, Esau cried out with a loud and sad cry. He said to his father, “Pray that good will come to me also, O my father!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Isaac said, “Your brother came in and fooled me. He has taken away the good that was to come to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau said, “Was it not right that he was given the name Jacob? Two times now he has taken what should have been mine. He took away my right as a first-born. And now he has taken away the good that was to come to me.” Then he said, “Can you not pray that good will come to me also?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaac answered Esau, “See, I have made him to rule over you. I have given him all his brothers as servants. I have given him grain and new wine to keep him alive and well. What then can I do for you, my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one prayer for good to come, my father? Pray that good will come to me also, O my father.” And Esau gave out a loud cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his father Isaac answered him: “See, the place where you live will be away from the riches of the earth, and away from the water on the grass in the early morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will live by your sword and you will serve your brother. But when you break loose, you will throw his load off your back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau hated Jacob because his father had prayed that good would come to Jacob. Esau said to himself, “The days when I will have sorrow for the loss of my father are soon. Then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the words of her older son Esau were told to Rebekah. She called her younger son Jacob, and said to him, “See, your brother Esau comforts himself by planning to kill you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, my son, do what I tell you. Get ready, and go at once to my brother Laban at Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay with him for a few days, until your brother’s anger goes away.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your brother’s anger against you is gone and he forgets what you did to him, then I will send for you and have you return from there. Why should I have sorrow for both of you in one day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am tired of living because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob marries one of the daughters of Heth, like these, from the women of the land, what good will my life be to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Isaac called Jacob and prayed that good would come to him. He said to him, “Do not marry one of the daughters of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get ready, and go to the house of your mother’s father Bethuel in Paddan-aram. Take a wife for yourself from the daughters of your mother’s brother Laban.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the All-powerful God bring good to you and give you many children until you become many nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: May He give you and your children after you the same gift that He gave Abraham. May He give you the land that He gave Abraham, the land where you are now a stranger.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaac sent Jacob away. And he went to Paddan-aram, to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Syrian, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob and Esau’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Esau saw that Isaac had prayed for good to come to Jacob and that he had sent him away to Paddan-aram to find a wife. Esau knew that his father had prayed for good to come to Jacob and said, “Do not marry one of the daughters of Canaan,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother and had gone to Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau knew that the daughters of Canaan did not please his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau went to Ishmael, and married Mahalath the daughter of Abraham’s son Ishmael, the sister of Nebaioth. He added her to the wives he already had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob left Beersheba and went toward Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to a certain place and stayed the night there, because the sun had gone down. He took one of the stones there and put it under his head for a pillow.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had a dream. He saw steps going up from the earth to heaven. He saw the angels of God going up and down these steps.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he saw the Lord standing above them. He said, “I am the Lord, the God of your father Abraham, and the God of Isaac. I will give to you and your children after you the land where you are lying.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be like the dust of the earth. You will spread out to the west and the east and the north and the south. Good will come to all the families of the earth because of you and your children.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I am with you. I will care for you everywhere you go. And I will bring you again to this land. For I will not leave you until I have done all the things I promised you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob awoke from his sleep and said, “For sure the Lord is in this place and I did not know it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He was afraid and said, “This place is so different! This is none other than the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob got up early in the morning. He took the stone he had used as a pillow, and set it up as a pillar. He poured oil on the top of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave that place the name Bethel. Its name had been Luz before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob made a promise. He said, “If God will be with me and take care of me as I go, and if He will give me food to eat and clothes to wear,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that I return in peace to my father’s house, then the Lord will be my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have set up this stone as a pillar to be God’s house. And I will give You a tenth part of all You give to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went on his way and came to the land of the people of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked up and saw a well in the field where three flocks of sheep were lying beside it. The people gave water to the flocks from that well. The stone covering the top of the well was large.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the flocks were gathered there, the men would roll the stone from the top of the well. Then after giving water to the sheep, they would put the stone again in its place on top of the well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to them, “My brothers, where are you from?” They said, “We are from Haran.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Do you know Laban the son of Nahor?” They said, “We know him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “Is he well?” They said, “He is well. And see, his daughter Rachel is coming with the sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “See, the sun is still high. It is not time for the flocks to be gathered. Give water to the sheep, and return them to their field.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “We cannot, until all the flocks are gathered and they roll the stone from the top of the well. Then we will give the sheep water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He was still talking with them when Rachel came with her father’s sheep, for she cared for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of his mother’s brother Laban, and the sheep of his mother’s brother Laban, Jacob went near and rolled the stone from the top of the well. And he gave water to the flock of his mother’s brother Laban.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and began to cry for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob told Rachel that he was of her father’s family, the son of Rebekah. And she ran and told her father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Laban heard the news of his sister’s son Jacob, he ran to meet him. He put his arms around him and kissed him, and brought him to his house. Then Jacob told Laban all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to him, “For sure you are my bone and my flesh.” And Jacob stayed with him a month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “Because you are one of my family, should you serve me for nothing? Tell me, what do you want to be paid?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Laban had two daughters. The name of the older one was Leah, and the name of the younger one was Rachel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah’s eyes were weak. But Rachel was beautiful in body and face.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob loved Rachel. So he said, “I will serve you seven years for your younger daughter Rachel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “It is better that I give her to you than to another man. Stay with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob worked seven years for Rachel. It was only like a few days to him, because of his love for her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife so I may go in to her. For my time is finished.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Laban gathered all the men of the place together, and made a special supper.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the evening he took his daughter Leah to him. Jacob went in to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban also took Zilpah, a woman who served him, and gave her to his daughter Leah, to serve her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the morning came, Jacob saw that it was Leah. He said to Laban, “What have you done to me? Did I not work for you for Rachel? Why have you fooled me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “It is not allowed in our country to give the younger in marriage before the first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: Complete the wedding week of this one. Then we will give you the other one also if you work for me seven years more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob did so and completed her wedding week. And Laban gave him his daughter Rachel as his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban also took Bilhah, a woman who served him, and gave her to his daughter Rachel, to serve her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob went in to Rachel also. He loved Rachel more than Leah. And he worked for Laban seven years more.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that Leah was not loved, He made her able to give birth. But Rachel could not give birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah was able to have a child and she gave birth to a son. She gave him the name Reuben. For she said, “The Lord has seen my trouble. Now my husband will love me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she was going to have another child and she gave birth to a son. She said, “The Lord has given me this son also, because He has heard that I am not loved.” So she gave him the name Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was going to have another child and she gave birth to a son. She said, “Now this time my husband will be joined to me because I have given birth to his three sons.” So she gave him the name Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was going to have another child and she gave birth to a son. And she said, “This time I will praise the Lord.” So she gave him the name of Judah. Then she stopped giving birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel saw that she had not given birth to any children for Jacob, she became jealous of her sister. She said to Jacob, “Give me children, or else I am going to die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became angry with Rachel. He said, “Am I taking God’s place, Who has kept you from giving birth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Here is Bilhah, the woman who serves me. Go in to her, and let her give birth for me. Even I may have children through her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she gave Bilhah to him for a wife, the woman who served her. And Jacob went in to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah was going to have a child and she gave birth to a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rachel said, “God has done the right thing for me. He has heard my voice and has given me a son.” So she gave him the name Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah, the woman who served Rachel, was going to have another child. And she gave birth to another son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel said, “I have fought a hard fight with my sister, and I have won.” She gave him the name Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah saw that she had stopped giving birth. So she took Zilpah, the woman who served her, and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a son was born to Jacob through Zilpah, the woman who served Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “Good things have happened to me!” So she gave him the name Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: A second son was born to Jacob through Zilpah, the woman who served Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “I am happy! For women will say that I am happy.” So she gave him the name Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the time of gathering grain, Reuben went out in the field and found some fruit. He brought it to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, “Give me some of your son’s fruit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Leah said, “Is it not enough to take my husband? Would you take my son’s fruit also?” So Rachel said, “Jacob may lie with you tonight if you give me your son’s fruit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob came in from the field in the evening, Leah went to meet him. She said, “You must sleep with me tonight. For I have paid for you with my son’s fruit.” So he lay with her that night.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God heard Leah and she gave birth to a fifth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah said, “God has given me my pay because I gave my husband the woman who serves me.” So she gave him the name Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah was going to have another child and she gave birth to a sixth son for Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Leah said, “God has given me a good gift. Now my husband will live with me, because I have given birth to six sons.” So she gave him the name of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later she gave birth to a daughter, and gave her the name Dinah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God remembered Rachel. God listened to her, and made her able to have a child,
speaker: Narrator

text: and she gave birth to a son. Then she said, “God has taken away my shame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave him the name Joseph, saying, “May the Lord give me another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me away, so I may go to my own place and my own country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served. Let me leave, for you know how much I have served you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Laban said to him, “If now it pleases you, stay with me. I have learned that the Lord has brought good to me because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Tell me what you want to be paid, and I will pay it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said to him, “You know how much I have served you and how I have cared for your cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you had little before I came. But now it has become very much. The Lord has brought good to you everywhere I turned. But when will I be able to give much to those of my own house also?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “What should I pay you?” Jacob said, “Do not pay me anything. If you will do this one thing for me, I will again feed and take care of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me go through your whole flock today. Let me take out of it every sheep and every goat that has spots, and every black lamb. These will be my pay.
speaker: Narrator

text: So my fair actions will answer for me later, when you come to look at what I have been paid. If you find any sheep or goat without spots or any lamb that is not black, you may think of them as stolen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Laban said, “Good! Let it be done as you say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That day Laban took out all the male goats with spots and all the female goats with spots, every one with white on it, and every black sheep. And he put them into the care of his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he traveled three days away from Jacob. And Jacob was left to care for the rest of Laban’s flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob took green sticks of three kinds of trees. And he cut white marks in them, showing the white which was in the sticks.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took these sticks which he had cut and set them in front of the flocks, in the place where the flocks came to drink. And the animals mated when they came to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the flocks mated in front of the sticks. And the young that were born had spots.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob divided the lambs. He made the flocks look toward Laban’s flock of the animals which were black or with spots. And he put his own flocks by themselves. He did not put them with Laban’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the stronger animals of the flock were mating, Jacob would put the sticks in the water in front of the flock so they would mate by the sticks.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the flock was weak, Jacob did not put the sticks in. So the weaker animals went to Laban and the stronger ones went to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob became very rich. He had large flocks and camels and donkeys, and men and women servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob heard the words of Laban’s sons, saying, “Jacob has taken away all that our father had. He has become rich with what had belonged to our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob saw that Laban did not show him as much favor as he did before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your fathers and to those of your family. And I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob called Rachel and Leah to come to his flock in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “I see that your father does not show me as much favor as he did before. But the God of my father has been with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that I have worked for your father with all my strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet your father has not been fair with me. He has changed my pay ten times. But God did not let him hurt me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he said, ‘The animals that have spots will be your pay,’ then all the flock gave birth to young ones with spots. If he said, ‘The animals with black marks will be your pay,’ then all the flock gave birth to young ones with black marks.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God has taken away your father’s animals and has given them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had a dream at the time the flocks were mating. I looked up and saw that the male goats which were mating with the female goats had black marks and spots.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of God said to me in the dream, ‘Jacob,’ and I said, ‘Here I am.’
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, ‘Look and see how all the male goats that are mating with the others have black marks and spots. For I have seen all that Laban has been doing to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the God of Bethel, where you set up a stone in honor to Me, and where you made a promise to Me. Now get up, leave this land, and return to the land of your birth.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Rachel and Leah answered him, “Do we still have any part or share in our father’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: Does he not think of us as strangers? For he has sold us. And he has used all the money that was paid for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the riches that God has taken away from our father belong to us and our children. So do whatever God has told you to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob got up and put his children and his wives on camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took away all his animals, all the riches he had gathered and all the cattle he had gathered in Paddan-aram. And he left to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban had gone to cut the wool from his flock. And Rachel stole the gods of her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob fooled Laban the Syrian by not telling him that he was going.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he left with all he had. He went and crossed the Euphrates River, and turned toward the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Laban was told on the third day that Jacob had gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took the men of his family with him, and followed Jacob for seven days. He found him in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God came to Laban the Syrian in a dream by night. He said to him, “Be careful that you do not speak good or bad to Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Laban came to Jacob. Now Jacob had put up his tent in the hill country. Laban and the men of his family put up their tents in the hill country of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to Jacob, “What do you mean by fooling me and carrying away my daughters as if they were taken by the sword?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you leave in secret and fool me? Why did you not tell me, so I would have sent you away with joy and with songs and with sounds of joy on the timbrel and harp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why did you not let me kiss my grandchildren and daughters good-bye? Now you have been foolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have the power to hurt you. But the God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, ‘Be careful not to speak good or bad to Jacob.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you have gone away because you had a desire for your father’s house. But why did you steal my gods?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob answered Laban, “Because I was afraid you might take your daughters from me and make them stay.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one with whom you find your gods will not live. In front of those of our family, look for what I have that is yours, and take it.” For Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Laban went into Jacob’s tent, and into Leah’s tent, and into the tent of the two women who served Rachel and Leah. But he did not find his gods. Then he went from Leah’s tent into Rachel’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rachel had taken the gods of Laban’s house and put them in the seat that was used on the camel’s back. And she sat upon them. Laban looked through the whole tent, but did not find them.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her father, “My lord, do not be angry that I cannot rise in front of you. For the way of women is upon me.” So he looked, but could not find the gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. Jacob said to Laban, “What have I done wrong? What is my sin that made you run after me?
speaker: Narrator

text: What things of your house have you found by looking through all that belongs to me? Set it here in front of my brothers and your brothers, so they may judge between us.
speaker: Narrator

text: During these twenty years I have been with you, your female goats and sheep have not lost a young one. And I have not eaten the sheep of your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not bring to you those that were torn by wild animals. I took the loss upon myself. You had me pay for what was carried away during the day or during the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the way it was for me. I suffered from heat during the day, and from cold during the night. And I could not sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been in your house twenty years. I worked for you fourteen years for your two daughters, and six years for your flock. And you changed my pay ten times.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the fear of Isaac, had not been with me, for sure you would have sent me away with nothing. God has seen my suffering and the work of my hands. So He spoke sharp words to you last night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban answered Jacob, “The daughters are my daughters. The children are my children. And the flocks are my flocks. All that you see is mine. But what can I do today to these my daughters or to their children who were born to them?
speaker: Narrator

text: So come now, let us make an agreement, you and I. And let us do something to show we have an agreement between us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up in honor of the agreement.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to the men of his family, “Gather stones.” So they took stones and put them on top of each other. And they ate there by all the stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban gave the stones the name of Jegar-sahadutha. But Jacob gave them the name Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said, “These stones are to stand for the agreement between you and me today.” So they were given the name Galeed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were given the name of Mizpah also. For Laban said, “May the Lord watch between you and me when we are apart from each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you hurt my daughters, or if you take wives other than my daughters, no man may see it. But God sees what happens between you and me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban said to Jacob, “See these stones that have been set up between you and me.
speaker: Narrator

text: These stones that have been set up will stand for our agreement. I will not pass by these stones to hurt you. And you will not pass by these stones to hurt me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The God of Abraham, the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.” So Jacob promised by the fear of his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob gave a gift in worship to God on the mountain. Then he called his brothers to eat bread. And they ate bread and stayed the night on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Laban got up early in the morning and kissed his grandchildren and daughters. He prayed that good would come to them. Then Laban left and returned home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob went on his way, and God’s angels met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob saw them, he said, “This is God’s camp!” So he gave the place the name Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent men to carry news before him to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “Say this to my lord Esau: ‘Your servant Jacob says, “I have been living with Laban, and stayed there until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have cattle and donkeys and flocks and men and women servants. And I have sent to tell my lord, hoping to find favor in your eyes.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men that carried the news returned to Jacob and said, “We came to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you, and four hundred men are with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob was afraid and troubled. And he divided the people who were with him, and the flocks and cattle and camels, into two groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he said, “If Esau comes to the one group and destroys it, then the other group will get away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said, “O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Lord, Who said to me, ‘Return to your country and to those of your family, and I will bring good to you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not earned any of the loving-kindness and faith which You have shown to your servant. For I had crossed this Jordan with only my walking stick. And now I have become two large groups.
speaker: Narrator

text: Save me, I pray, from the hand of my brother, from the power of Esau. For I am afraid of him. I am afraid he will come and kill us all, the mothers with the children.
speaker: Narrator

text: But You said, ‘I will bring good to you. I will make your children like the sand of the sea. There will be too many to number.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob stayed there that night. Then he chose a gift from what he had for his brother Esau:
speaker: Narrator

text: Two hundred female goats, twenty male goats, two hundred female sheep, twenty rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: thirty milk camels and their young ones, forty cows, ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put them into the care of his servants, every group of animals by itself. Then he said to his servants, “Go in front of me. And keep the groups of animals apart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the one in front, “When my brother Esau meets you and asks, ‘To whom do you belong, and where are you going, and who owns these animals in front of you?’
speaker: Narrator

text: then you say, ‘These belong to your servant Jacob. It is a gift sent to my lord Esau. And he is coming behind us.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He also told the second and the third and all those who followed the animals, “This is what you are to say to Esau when you meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And be sure to say, ‘Your servant Jacob is coming behind us.’” For he said, “I will take away his anger with the gift that goes in front of me. Then when I meet him, he might receive me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the gift went in front of him, while he stayed that night in the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he got up that same night and crossed the Jabbok River, with his two wives, the two women who served him, and his eleven children.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took them and sent them to the other side of the river with all that he had.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob was left alone. And a man fought with him until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man saw that he was not winning he touched the joint of Jacob’s thigh. And Jacob’s thigh was put out of joint while he fought with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said, “Let me go. For the morning has come.” But Jacob said, “I will not let you go unless you pray that good will come to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man asked him, “What is your name?” He said, “Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel. For you have fought with God and with men, and have won.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob asked him, “Tell me, what is your name?” But he said, “Why is it that you ask my name?” And there he prayed that good would come to Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob gave the place the name of Peniel. For he said, “I have seen God face to face, and yet I am still alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun rose upon him as he passed through Peniel. It was hard to walk on his leg.
speaker: Narrator

text: So to this day the sons of Israel do not eat the meat from inside the joint of the thigh, because he touched this part of the joint on Jacob’s leg.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob looked up and saw Esau coming with 400 men. So he divided the children among Leah and Rachel and the two women who served him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the women who served him and their children in front, and Leah and her children behind them, and Rachel and Joseph behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob went before them. He bowed to the ground seven times, until he came near his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau ran to meet him and put his arms around him and kissed him. And they cried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau looked up and saw the women and the children. He said, “Who are these with you?” Jacob said, “They are the children whom God, in His loving-favor, has given your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the women who served Jacob came near with their children, and they bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leah also came near with her children, and they bowed to the ground. Then Joseph and Rachel came near and bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau said, “What do you mean by all these animals I have met?” And Jacob said, “They are a gift so I may find favor in the eyes of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Esau said, “I have enough, my brother. Keep what you have for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said, “No, I ask of you, if I have found favor in your eyes, then receive my gift. For I see your face as one sees the face of God. You have received me with favor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take my gift that has been brought to you. For God has shown loving-kindness to me, and I have all I need.” So he begged him until he took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau said, “Let us be on our way. I will go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are weak. And there are young ones in my flocks that need milk. If they are made to go a long way in one day, all the flocks will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let my lord go in front of his servant. And I will be slow in coming to my lord at Seir. I will go as fast as the cattle in front of me and as the children are able.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau said, “Let me leave with you some of the people who are with me.” But Jacob said, “What need is there? Let me find favor in the eyes of my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau returned that day on his way to Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob traveled to Succoth. He built his house there, and put up small buildings for his animals. So the name of the place is Succoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob came in peace from Paddan-aram to the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan. And he put up his tents near the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bought the piece of land where he had put up his tents for one hundred pieces of money from the sons of Hamor, Shechem’s father.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built an altar there, and gave it the name El-Elohe-Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Leah’s daughter Dinah, who was born to Jacob, went out to visit the women of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she was seen by Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivite, the ruler of the land. He took her and made her lay with him, and she was put to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had much desire for Dinah the daughter of Jacob. He loved the girl and spoke kind words to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Shechem said to his father Hamor, “Get me this young girl for a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob heard that Shechem had put his daughter Dinah to shame. But his sons were with the flocks in the field, so Jacob kept quiet until they returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shechem’s father Hamor went to speak with Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob’s sons returned from the field when they heard what had happened. They were full of sorrow and were angry. For Shechem had put Israel to shame by lying with Jacob’s daughter. Such a thing should not be done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hamor said to them, “The soul of my son Shechem has much desire for your daughter. I ask of you, give her to him in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: Marry with our people. Give your daughters to us. And take our daughters for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: May you live with us. And the land will be open to you. Live and trade in it, and buy land in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shechem said to Dinah’s father and brothers, “Let me find favor in your eyes. I will give you whatever you ask.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make your price and wedding gift as much as you want. I will give you as much as you ask. Only give me the girl to be my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob’s sons lied in their answer to Shechem and his father Hamor because he had put their sister Dinah to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to them, “We cannot do this. We cannot give our sister to one who has not gone through the religious act of having his flesh cut. For that would be a shame to us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will give you our sister only if you become like us. Every man among you must have this religious act done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we will give our daughters to you. And we will marry your daughters. We will live with you and become one people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you will not listen to us and have this religious act done, then we will take our daughter and go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Their words pleased Hamor and his son Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man did not wait to do what they asked, because he was in love with Jacob’s daughter. And he was the most honored of all his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hamor and his son Shechem came to the gate of their city. And they said to the men of their city,
speaker: Narrator

text: “These men want to be at peace with us. Let them live in the land and trade in it. For, see, the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters in marriage, and give our daughters to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men will be willing to live with us and become one people only if every man among us goes through the religious act that they have gone through.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not their cattle and all they own, all their animals, be ours? Let us just do what they ask, and they will live with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All who went out of the gate of his city listened to Hamor and his son Shechem. And every man went through the religious act of having his flesh cut, all who went out of the gate of his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the third day, when all the men were in pain, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, took their swords and went into the city in secret. And they killed every man.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with the sword. And they took Dinah from Shechem’s house and went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob’s sons went over the dead men and robbed the city of its riches because its men had put their sister to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their flocks and cattle and donkeys and whatever was in the city and in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all their riches, their little ones, their wives, even all that was in the houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought trouble on me by making me hated by the people of the land, the Canaanites and Perizzites. My men are few in number. And these people will gather together against me and fight me. I and those of my house will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “Should he act towards our sister as if she were a woman who sells the use of her body?”
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to Jacob, “Get ready and go to Bethel to live. Make an altar there to God, Who showed Himself to you when you ran away from your brother Esau.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob said to those of his house and all who were with him, “Put away the strange gods that are among you. Make yourselves clean and change your clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then let us get ready and go to Bethel. I will make an altar there to God, Who answered me in the day of my trouble, and was with me every place I went.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gave to Jacob all the strange gods they had, and the gold objects which they wore in their ears. And Jacob hid them under the tree near Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they traveled, much fear from God came upon the cities around them. So the people of the land did not go against the sons of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob and all the people who were with him came to Luz (that is, Bethel) in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built an altar there, and gave the place the name El-bethel. Because God had shown Himself to him there, when Jacob ran away from his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rebekah’s nurse Deborah died. She was buried below Bethel under a tree. It was given the name of Allon-bacuth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob came from Paddan-aram, God showed Himself to him again and brought good to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob. You will not be called Jacob any longer, but Israel will be your name.” So his name was Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God said to him, “I am the All-powerful God. Have many children and add to your number. A nation and a group of nations will come from you. Kings will come from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you the land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac. This land I will give to your children and their children’s children after you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God went up from him in the place where He had spoken with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a pillar of stone in the place where He had spoken with him. And he poured a drink offering and also oil on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob gave the place where God had spoken with him the name Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled from Bethel. When there was still a long way to go before coming to Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth. She suffered much pain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while she was suffering, the woman who was helping her said to her, “Do not be afraid. For now you have another son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Rachel’s soul was leaving, for she died, she gave him the name Benoni. But his father gave him the name Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Rachel died, and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob set up a stone on her grave. And that is the stone of Rachel’s grave to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel traveled on, and put up his tent on the other side of the tall building of Eder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While Israel lived in that land, Reuben went and lay with Bilhah, the woman who acted as his father’s wife. And Israel heard about it.
There were twelve sons of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Leah were Reuben, Jacob’s first-born, then Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bilhah, the woman who served Rachel, were Dan and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zilpah, the woman who served Leah, were Gad and Asher. These are the sons who were born to Jacob in Paddan-aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob came to his father Isaac at Mamre of Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had been living.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Isaac had lived 180 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaac breathed his last and died, and was joined to his people who died before him. He was an old man who had a long life, and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children of Esau (that is, Edom).
speaker: Narrator

text: Esau took his wives from the women of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ishmael’s daughter Basemath, the sister of Nebaioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adah gave birth to Esau’s son Eliphaz. Basemath gave birth to Reuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Oholibamah gave birth to Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These are the sons who were born to Esau in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Esau took his wives and sons and daughters and all those of his house, and his flocks and cattle, and all his riches from the land of Canaan. And he went to another land away from his brother Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they owned too much for them to live together. The land where they were staying could not keep them alive, because of all their animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Esau lived in the hill country of Seir. Esau is Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the children, and their children, of Esau the father of the Edomites in the hill country of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz the son of Esau’s wife Adah, and Reuel the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Timna acted as the wife of Esau’s son Eliphaz. And she gave birth to Eliphaz’s son Amalek. These are the sons of Esau’s wife Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. They are the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon: She gave birth to Esau’s sons, Jeush, Jalam and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders of the sons of Esau. The sons of Esau’s first-born, Eliphaz, are leaders Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These are the leaders of Eliphaz in the land of Edom. They are the sons of Adah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau’s son Reuel: Leaders Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These are the leaders of Reuel in the land of Edom. They are the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: Leaders Jeush, Jalam and Korah. These are the leaders of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Esau (that is, Edom), and these are their leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Seir the Horite, who lived in that land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These are the leaders of the Horites, the sons of Seir in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Lotan are Hori and Hemam. Lotan’s sister was Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shobal are Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zibeon are Aiah and Anah. He is the Anah who found the hot water well in the desert when he was caring for the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Anah are Dishon and Oholibamah, Anah’s daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Dishon are Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ezer are Bilhan, Zaavan and Akan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sons of Dishan are Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders of the Horites: Leaders Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These are the leaders of the Horites, by their families in the land of Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before any king ruled the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bela the son of Beor ruled in Edom. The name of his city was Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bela died. And Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jobab died. And Husham of the land of the Temanites became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Husham died. And Hadad the son of Bedad, who won the fight against Midian in the field of Moab, became king in his place. The name of his city was Avith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hadad died. And Samlah of Masrekah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Samlah died. And Shaul of Rehoboth on the Euphrates River became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shaul died. And Achbor’s son Baalhanan became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Achbor’s son died. And Hadar became king in his place. The name of his city was Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, daughter of Mezahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the leaders of Esau, by family, place and name: Leaders Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram. These are the leaders of Edom (that is, Esau, the father of the Edomites), who lived in the land that belonged to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob lived in the land where his father had lived as a stranger, in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the story of the children of Jacob and of their children.
When Joseph was seventeen years old, he was caring for the flock with his brothers. The boy was with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives. And Joseph told his father about how bad they were.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons, because Joseph was born when he was an old man. And Israel made him a long coat of many colors.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers. So they hated Joseph and could not speak a kind word to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph had a dream. When he told it to his brothers, they hated him even more.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Listen to the dream that I have had.
speaker: Narrator

text: We were gathering grain in the field. My bundle of grain stood up. Your bundles of grain gathered around it and bowed down to my bundle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers said to him, “Are you going to be our king? Are you going to rule over us?” So they hated him even more for his dreams and for what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he had another dream, and he told it to his brothers. He said, “I have had another dream. The sun and the moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told it to his father and to his brothers. His father spoke sharp words to him, saying, “What is this dream you have had? Will I and your mother and brothers come to bow ourselves down to the ground in front of you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s brothers were jealous of him. But his father thought about what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers went to feed their father’s flock in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to Joseph, “Are not your brothers feeding the flock in Shechem? Come, I will send you to them.” And Joseph said to him, “I will go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel said, “Go now, see if it is well with your brothers and with the flock. Then come and tell me.” So he sent him from the valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man found him walking through a field, and asked him, “What are you looking for?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said, “I am looking for my brothers. Tell me where they are feeding the flock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man said, “They have moved from here. For I heard them say, ‘Let us go to Dothan.’” So Joseph followed his brothers and found them at Dothan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him far away, before he came near them, they made plans to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to one another, “Here comes this dreamer!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now come and let us kill him and throw him into one of the deep holes. Then we will say that a wild animal ate him. And we will see what becomes of his dreams!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Reuben heard this and saved him from their hands, saying, “Let us not kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben then said, “Do not put him to death. Throw him into this hole here in the desert. But do not lay a hand on him.” He wanted to be able to save Joseph and return him to his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when Joseph came to his brothers, they tore off his coat, the coat of many colors that he was wearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they took him and threw him into the hole. The hole was empty and had no water in it.
speaker: Narrator
