text: Then they sat down to eat. When they looked up, they saw a group of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. They were taking spices and perfumes on their camels to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said to his brothers, “What do we get by killing our brother and covering his blood?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let us sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay our hands on him. For he is our brother, our own flesh.” And his brothers listened to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some Midianite traders were passing by. So the brothers pulled Joseph up out of the hole. And they sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver, and they took Joseph to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Reuben returned to the hole. When he saw that Joseph was not in the hole, he tore his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He returned to his brothers and said, “The boy is not there! What can I do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took Joseph’s coat, killed a male goat, and put the blood on the coat.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sent the coat of many colors to their father. And they said, “We found this. Is it your son’s coat or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob looked at it and said, “It is my son’s coat! A wild animal has eaten him! For sure Joseph has been torn to pieces!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jacob tore his clothes and dressed in clothes made from hair. He had sorrow for his son many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his sons and daughters tried to comfort him. But he would not be comforted. He said, “I will go down to the grave in sorrow for my son.” And his father cried for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, the head of the soldiers of Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah went away from his brothers at that time. He visited a certain Adullamite whose name was Hirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There Judah saw a daughter of a certain Canaanite whose name was Shua. He took her as his wife and lived with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she was going to have a child and gave birth to a son. He gave him the name Er.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she was going to have another child and she gave birth to a son. She gave him the name Onan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she gave birth to another son at Chezib. And she gave him the name Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah chose a wife for his first-born son Er. Her name was Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Er, Judah’s first-born, was sinful in the eyes of the Lord. So the Lord took his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Go in to your brother’s wife. Do your duty as her brother-in-law. Have children for your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Onan knew that the children would not be his. So when he went in to his brother’s wife, he wasted his seed on the ground to keep his brother from having children.
speaker: Narrator

text: What he did was sinful in the eyes of the Lord. So the Lord took his life also.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Stay in your father’s house as a woman whose husband has died, until my son Shelah is grown.” For he thought, “I am afraid that he also may die like his brothers.” So Tamar went and lived in her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after a long time, Shua’s daughter, the wife of Judah, died. And after the time of sorrow, Judah and his friend Hirah the Adullamite went to the men who cut the wool from his sheep at Timnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was told to Tamar, “Your father-in-law is going to Timnah to cut the wool from his sheep.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she took off the clothes of a woman whose husband has died and put on other clothes and covered her face with cloth. Then she sat in the gate of Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah. For she saw that Shelah was grown, and she had not been given to him for a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a woman who sold the use of her body. For she had covered her face.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went to her at the side of the road, and said, “Here now, let me come in to you.” He did not know that she was his daughter-in-law. And she said, “What will you give me to come in to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “I will send you a young goat from the flock.” She asked, “Will you give something as a promise until you send it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What should I give you as a promise?” And she said, “The ring you use to mark your name, and its string, and the stick that is in your hand.” So he gave them to her and went in to her. And she was going to have a baby by him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she got up and left. She took off the cloth that covered her, and put on the clothes worn by a woman whose husband has died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah sent his friend the Adullamite to bring the young goat to the woman and take from her the things he had given as a promise. But he did not find her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked the men of the place, “Where is the woman who was selling the use of her body beside the road at Enaim?” They said, “There has been no woman selling the use of her body here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned to Judah, and said, “I did not find her. The men of the place said, ‘There has been no woman selling the use of her body here.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah said, “Let her keep the things, or else we will be laughed at. I sent the young goat, and you did not find her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: About three months later, Judah was told, “Your daughter-in-law Tamar has sold the use of her body. She is going to have a baby by doing this sinful thing.” Judah said, “Bring her out and let her be burned!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When she was brought out, she sent word to her father-in-law, “I am going to have a baby by the man who owns these things.” She said, “Look and see, who owns this ring for marking a name, and this string and stick?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah saw that they belonged to him. He said, “She is more right than I, because I did not give her to my son Shelah.” And he did not lie with her again.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came for Tamar to give birth, there were two babies.
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was giving birth, one put out a hand. The nurse took his hand and tied a red string around it, saying, “This one came out first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he pulled away his hand, his brother was born. Then she said, “What an opening you have made for yourself!” So he was given the name of Perez.
speaker: Narrator

text: After that, his brother came out with the red string around his hand. He was given the name Zerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joseph had been taken down to Egypt by the Ishmaelites. And Potiphar, an Egyptian leader, the head of the soldiers of Pharaoh’s house, bought him from the Ishmaelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was with Joseph, and all went well with him. He was in the house of his boss the Egyptian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now his boss saw that the Lord was with him. He saw how the Lord made all that Joseph did go well.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph found favor in his eyes, and worked only for him. Potiphar made him the one to watch over his house and take care of all that he owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the time that he watched over his house and all he owned, the Lord brought good to the Egyptian’s house because of Joseph. The Lord brought good upon all that he owned in the house and in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he put all he owned in Joseph’s care. Having Joseph near, he did not need to think about anything but the food he ate. Now Joseph was strong and good-looking.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time came when his boss’s wife saw him, and she said, “Lie with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he would not do it. He said to his boss’s wife, “See, with me near, my boss does not worry about anything in the house. He has put all he owns in my care.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no one more important in this house than I. And he has held nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do this sinful thing, and sin against God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She spoke to Joseph day after day. But he did not listen to her. He would not lie with her or be with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one day Joseph went into the house to do his work. None of the men of the house were inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: She caught him by his coat, saying, “Lie with me!” But he ran out of the house leaving the coat in her hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she saw that he had left his coat in her hand and had run out of the house,
speaker: Narrator

text: she called the men of her house. And she said to them, “See, this Hebrew has been brought to us to make fun of us. He came in to lie with me, and I cried out with a loud voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard my loud cry, he left his coat with me and ran outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She kept his coat with her until his boss came home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she told him the same story, saying, “The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us came to me to lie with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I called out in a loud voice, he left his coat with me and ran outside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When his boss heard his wife’s story and her words, “This is what your servant did to me,” he became very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph’s boss took him and put him in prison, the place where the men who did wrong against the king were put in chains. So there he was in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was with Joseph, and showed him kindness. He gave him favor in the eyes of the man who watched over the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head of the prison put all the men who were in prison into Joseph’s care. So whatever was done there was because of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head of the prison did not worry about anything under Joseph’s care, because the Lord was with him. The Lord made all go well with whatever Joseph did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, the man who carried the king’s cup and the man who made the king’s bread did wrong against the king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was angry with these two important men, the head cup-carrier and the head bread-maker.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he put them in prison under the care of the head of the soldiers, the same place where Joseph was in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: The head of the soldiers had Joseph watch over them. He took care of them, and they were in prison for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: One night both the cup-carrier and the bread-maker of the king of Egypt had a dream while they were in prison. Each man had his own dream, and each dream had its own meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came in and looked at them in the morning, he saw that they were sad.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he asked these men who had worked for Pharaoh and who were with him in prison in his boss’s house, “Why are your faces so sad today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “We have had a dream and there is no one to tell us what it means.” Then Joseph said to them, “Do not the meanings of dreams belong to God? Tell them to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the head cup-carrier told his dream to Joseph. He said, “In my dream, there was a vine in front of me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there were three branches on the vine. Then its flowers grew out. From the many flowers came grapes ready to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand. So I took the grapes and made wine from them and poured it into Pharaoh’s cup. And I put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to him, “This is the meaning of it: The three branches are three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before three days are over, Pharaoh will give you honor and return you to your place of work. You will put Pharaoh’s cup into his hand just like you did before when you were his cup-carrier.
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember me when it is well with you, and show me kindness. Say a good word about me to Pharaoh. Get me out of this prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I was stolen from the land of the Hebrews. And here also I have done nothing for which they should put me in prison.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The head bread-maker saw that the meaning of the dream was good. He said to Joseph, “I had a dream also. There were three baskets of white bread on my head.
speaker: Narrator

text: All kinds of food for Pharaoh were in the top basket. But the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph answered, “This is the meaning of it: The three baskets are three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head from you and put your body up on a tree. And the birds will eat the flesh from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, Pharaoh’s birthday, he made a special supper for his servants. He gave honor to the head cup-carrier and the head bread-maker among his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He returned the head cup-carrier to his place of work and he put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he killed the head bread-maker on a tree, just like Joseph had told them it would happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the head cup-carrier did not remember Joseph. He forgot him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After two years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream. He dreamed that he was standing by the Nile River.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he saw seven cows coming out of the Nile. They were good-looking and fat, and they ate the grass beside the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he saw seven other cows coming out of the Nile after them. They looked bad and were thin. They stood by the other cows beside the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the bad looking cows that were thin ate the seven good-looking, fat cows, and Pharaoh awoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he fell asleep and dreamed a second time. He saw seven heads of grain growing on one stick of grain. They were large and full.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he saw seven heads of grain come after them, which were small and made dry by the east wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the small heads of grain ate the seven large, full heads of grain.
Then Pharaoh awoke and saw that it was a dream.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when morning came his spirit was troubled. He called for all the wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams. But there was no one who could tell Pharaoh the meaning of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the head cup-carrier said to Pharaoh, “I remember today what I have done wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was angry with his servants. And he put me and the head bread-maker in prison in the house of the head of the soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He and I had a dream on the same night. Each dream had its own meaning.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young Hebrew was there with us. He worked for the head of the soldiers. We told our dreams to him. And he told us the meaning of them. He told each of us what our different dreams meant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it happened just like he had said it would. I was returned to my place of work. The bread-maker was killed on a tree.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh then called for Joseph. And they brought him out of the prison in a hurry. He cut off the hair on his face and put on clean clothes. Then he came to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I have had a dream. But no one can tell me what it means. I have heard it said that you are able to hear a dream and tell what it means.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph answered Pharaoh, “Not by myself. God will give Pharaoh a good answer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream, I was standing beside the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw seven cows coming out of the Nile. They were fat and good-looking, and they ate the grass beside the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw seven other cows coming after them. They looked bad and were thin. I had never seen worse cows in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the bad looking cows that were thin ate the first seven fat cows.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after they had eaten them, it could not be seen that they had eaten them. For they were just as bad looking as before. Then I awoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw also in my dream seven heads of grain growing on one stick of grain. They were large and full.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw seven heads of grain come after them. They were small and were dry because of the east wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The small heads of grain ate the seven good heads of grain. Then I told it to the wise men. But there was no one who could tell me what it means.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to Pharaoh, “Pharaoh’s dreams are one and the same. God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven good cows are seven years. And the seven good heads of grain are seven years. The dreams are one and the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven bad looking cows that are thin that came up after them are seven years. And the seven small heads of grain made dry by the east wind mean seven years without food.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is as I have said to Pharaoh. God has shown Pharaoh what He is about to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven years are coming when there will be much food in all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after them will come seven years when there will be no food. The time of much food will be forgotten in the land of Egypt. The time of no food will destroy the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time without food will be so hard that no one in the land will remember when they had much.
speaker: Narrator

text: That the dream was sent twice to Pharaoh shows that what will happen is planned by God. And God will make it happen soon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now let Pharaoh look for a man who is understanding and wise. Let the land of Egypt be put into his care.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let Pharaoh take action to choose men to watch over the land. And let him take a fifth part of the food of the land of Egypt during the seven years of much food.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them gather all the food of these good years that are coming. Have them store the grain under the power of Pharaoh, to be used as food in the cities. And let them keep it safe.
speaker: Narrator

text: This food will be kept for the people to eat during the seven years of no food that will come upon the land of Egypt. This way the land will not be destroyed during the time without food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The plan pleased Pharaoh and all his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to his servants, “Can we find a man like this, who has in him the Spirit of God?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Because God has shown you all this, there is no one as understanding and wise as you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: My house will be put in your care. And all my people will do as you say. Only on the throne will I be greater than you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “See, I have put you in power over all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh took the ring from his hand, and put it on Joseph’s hand. He dressed him in clothes of fine cloth. He put a gold chain around his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had him travel in his second wagon of honor. And they called out in front of him, “Bow down!” Pharaoh put him in power over all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh. But unless it is your will, no one will raise his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh gave Joseph the name of Zaphenath-paneah. He gave him for a wife Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera who was the religious leader of On. So Joseph went out through the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was thirty years old when he stood in front of Pharaoh, king of Egypt. And Joseph went from Pharaoh to visit every part of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the seven good years the land brought much food.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he gathered into the cities all the food of these seven years when there was much in the land of Egypt. He put into each city the food from the fields around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph gathered as much grain as the sand of the sea. The time came when he stopped trying to know how much there was.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two sons were born to Joseph before the years without food came. Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, the religious leader of On, gave birth to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph gave the first-born the name Manasseh. “For,” he said, “God has made me forget all my trouble and all those of my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave the second son the name of Ephraim. “For,” he said, “God has given me children in the land of my suffering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The seven good years of much food in the land of Egypt came to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the seven bad years of no food began, as Joseph had said. No food was growing in all the lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was food.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when all the people of Egypt were hungry, they cried to Pharaoh for bread. Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph. Do what he tells you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the hunger was spreading over all the earth, Joseph opened the store-houses. And he sold food to the Egyptians for the time without food had become hard in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of all the earth came to Egypt to buy grain from Joseph because the time without food was hard everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jacob learned that there was grain in Egypt. He said to his sons, “Why are you looking at one another?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go there and buy some for us, so we may live and not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So ten of Joseph’s brothers went to buy grain in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob did not send Joseph’s brother Benjamin with his brothers. For he said, “I am afraid that something will happen to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the sons of Israel joined those who were coming to buy grain for there was no food in Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph was the ruler of the land. He was the one who sold grain to all the people of the land. And Joseph’s brothers came and bowed to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw his brothers, he knew who they were. But he acted like a stranger and spoke sharp words to them. He said, “Where have you come from?” They answered, “From the land of Canaan, to buy food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph knew his brothers but they did not know him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph remembered the dreams he had had about them. He said to them, “You are spies. You have come to find the weak places in our land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “No, my lord. Your servants have come to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are all sons of one man. We do not lie. Your servants are not working against you in secret.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “No! You have come to find the weak places in our land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they said, “Your servants are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is now with our father. And one is no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph said to them, “It is as I said. You are spies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be put to a test. By the life of Pharaoh, you will not leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here.
speaker: Narrator

text: Send one of you to bring your brother, and the rest of you will be kept in prison. Your words will be put to a test to see if you are telling the truth. Or else, by the life of Pharaoh, you are spies for sure.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He put them all together in prison for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to them on the third day, “Do this and live, for I fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are men who do not lie, let one of your brothers stay here in prison for all of you. But you others go and carry grain for your hungry families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring your youngest brother to me, so your words will be proven true. And you will live.” So they did what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to one another, “For sure we are guilty for what we did to our brother. We saw the suffering of his soul while he begged us. But we would not listen. So this trouble has come to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben answered them, “Did I not tell you, ‘Do not sin against the boy?’ But you would not listen. Now we must pay for his blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They did not know that Joseph understood them. For there was a man between them to tell the meaning of each other’s language.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph went away from them and cried. Then he returned to speak with them. And he took Simeon from them and put chains on him in front of his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph had their bags filled with grain. He had each man’s money returned to his bag, to buy what was needed as they traveled. So this was done for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they loaded their donkeys with their grain, and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When one of them opened his bag to give his donkey food at the place where they were staying the night, he saw his money. It was there at the top of his bag.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his brothers, “My money has been returned! It is inside my bag!” Then their hearts became full of fear. They turned to each other, shaking in fear, saying, “What is this that God has done to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him all that had happened to them. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who is ruler of the land spoke sharp words to us. He thought that we had gone there to find the weak places in the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we said to him, ‘We do not lie. We are not working against you in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text: We are twelve brothers, the sons of our father. One is no more. And the youngest is now with our father in the land of Canaan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man who is ruler of the land said to us, ‘I will know that you are telling the truth by this test. Leave one of your brothers with me. Take grain for your hungry families and go.
speaker: Narrator

text: But bring your youngest brother to me, so I will know you are not spies, but honest men telling the truth. Then I will return your brother to you. And then you may trade in the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they took the grain out of their bags, they found that every man’s money was in his bag. And when they and their father saw the money, they were afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father Jacob said to them, “You have taken my children from me! Joseph is no more. Simeon is no more. And now you would take Benjamin! All this has come upon me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Reuben told his father, “You may kill my two sons if I do not return him to you. Put him in my care, and I will return him to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jacob said, “My son will not go with you. For his brother is dead, and only he is left. If something were to happen to him during your traveling, you would bring my white hair down to the grave in sorrow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The time of no food was hard in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had eaten all the grain they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them, “Go again and buy us a little food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Judah told him, “The man said to us with sharp words, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If you send our brother with us, we will go to Egypt and buy you food.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do not send him, we will not go. For the man said, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said, “Why did you do me such a wrong by telling the man that you had another brother?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “The man asked questions about us and our family. He said, ‘Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?’ So we answered his questions. How could we know that he would say, ‘Bring your brother here’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said to his father Israel, “Send the boy with me. And we will get up and go, so we and you and our children may live and not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put myself as trust for him. You may put him in my care. If I do not return him to you and set him in front of you, then let the blame be on me forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we had not waited, we would have returned twice by now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then their father Israel said to them, “If it must be so, then do this: take some of the best things of the land in your bags. Carry them to the man as a gift. Give him perfume and honey and spices and special things to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take twice as much money with you to take the place of the money that was returned in your bags. It may be that it was a mistake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your brother also. Get up, and return to the man.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the All-powerful God give you such favor with the man that he may let your other brother and Benjamin return. If my children are taken from me, I am filled with sorrow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men took the gift, and twice as much money, and Benjamin. They got up and went to Egypt, and stood in front of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the man who took care of his house, “Bring the men into the house. And kill an animal and make it ready. For the men will eat with me at noon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man did what Joseph said, and brought the men to Joseph’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were afraid because they were brought to Joseph’s house. They said, “We are being brought in because of the money that was returned in our bags the first time we came. He is looking for something against us. He will come down on us and take us for servants with our donkeys.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came near the man who took care of Joseph’s house, and spoke to him at the door of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “O, my lord, we came here the first time to buy food.
speaker: Narrator

text: When we came to the place where we stayed the night, we opened our bags. And we found that the full weight of each man’s money was at the top of the bag. So we have brought it again with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have brought other money with us also to buy food. We do not know who put our money in our bags.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he answered, “Peace be with you. Do not be afraid. Your God and the God of your father has given you riches in your bags. I received your money.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man brought the men into Joseph’s house and gave them water to wash their feet. And he fed their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they made the gift ready to give to Joseph when he came at noon. For they had heard that they were to eat there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph came home, they gave him the gift they had brought with them. They bowed to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph asked them about their well-being. He said, “Is your father well, the old man you spoke about? Is he still alive?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “Your servant, our father is well. He is still alive.” Then they bowed their heads low in honor to Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he looked up, he saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son. He said, “Is this your youngest brother whom you told me about? May God show you loving-favor, my son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph went out in a hurry. For he had much feeling for his brother. He went in his room and cried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he washed his face and came out. Hiding his feelings, he said, “Bring the food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought food to Joseph by himself, and to them by themselves, and to the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves. The Egyptians could not eat bread with the Hebrews because they thought it would be sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph’s brothers were seated in front of him by the way they were born, from the oldest to the youngest. And the men looked at each other in wonder.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph took food to them from his own table. But Benjamin’s food was five times as much as any of theirs. And they were free in eating and drinking with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph told the man who took care of his house, “Fill the men’s bags with as much food as they can carry. And put each man’s money in his bag.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put my silver cup in the bag of the youngest, with his money for the grain.” And he did what Joseph had told him to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early in the morning the men were sent away with their donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they had left the city and were not far away, Joseph said to the man who took care of his house, “Get up and follow the men. When you come to them, say to them, ‘Why have you returned bad for good? Why have you stolen the silver cup?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this not my lord’s drinking cup that he uses for telling about the future? You have done wrong.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he came to them and spoke these words to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to him, “Why does my lord say these things? Your servants would never do such a thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember how we returned to you from the land of Canaan with the money we found in the top of our bags. Why then would we steal silver or gold from your owner’s house?
speaker: Narrator

text: If the cup is found with any of your servants, let him be put to death. And the others of us will be your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “Let it be as you say. He who is found to have the cup will be my servant. But you others will be without blame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then each man put his bag down on the ground in a hurry and opened it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man looked for it, beginning with the oldest and stopping with the youngest. And the cup was found in Benjamin’s bag.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they tore their clothes. After each man loaded his donkey again, they returned to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Judah and his brothers came to Joseph’s house, he was still there. They fell to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to them, “What is this that you have done? Did you not know that a man like me has power to know what is not known by others?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah said, “We do not know what to say to my lord. How can we make ourselves right in your eyes? God has shown the guilt of your servants. See, we are your servants, both we and the one who was found with the cup.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph said, “No. I will do no such thing. The person who was found with the cup will be my servant. But you others may go in peace to your father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Judah came near to him, and said, “O my lord, let your servant speak a word in my lord’s ears. Do not be angry with your servant. For you are like Pharaoh himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: My lord asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
speaker: Narrator

text: We said to my lord, ‘We have an old father and a young brother who was born to him when he was old. Now his brother is dead. So he is all that is left of his mother, and his father loves him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you said to your servants, ‘Bring him here to me, so I may see him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But we said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father. For if he should leave his father, his father would die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you said to your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes here with you, you will not see my face again.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When we returned to your servant my father, we told him what my lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Our father said, ‘Go again and buy us a little food.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But we said, ‘We cannot go there. If our youngest brother is with us, we will go there. For we cannot see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then your servant my father said to us, ‘You know that my wife gave birth to two of my sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: One left me, and I said, “For sure he is torn to pieces.” I have not seen him since.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you take this one also from me, and something happens to him, you will bring my white hair down to the grave in sorrow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: My father’s life and the boy’s life are one. If I return to your servant my father, and the boy is not with us,
speaker: Narrator

text: when he sees that the boy is not with us, he will die. So your servants will bring the white hair of your servant our father down to the grave in sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I put myself as trust for the boy to my father. I said, ‘If I do not return him to you, then let the blame be on me forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So let your servant stay and work for my lord, instead of the boy. Let the boy go home with his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: For how can I return to my father if the boy is not with me? I am afraid to see the sorrow that my father would suffer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph could not hide his feelings in front of all who stood by him. He cried, “Send all the people away from me.” So no one was with him when Joseph told his brothers who he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried so loud that the Egyptians heard it, and those of Pharaoh’s house heard of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still alive?” But his brothers could not answer him, for they were afraid in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “Come near to me.” So they came near. He said, “I am your brother Joseph, whom you sold into Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not be troubled or angry with yourselves because you sold me here. For God sent me before you to save your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the land has been without food these two years. And there are five more years without plowing or gathering.
speaker: Narrator

text: God sent me before you to make sure that your people will keep living on the earth. Now many of you will be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it was not you who sent me here, but God. He has made me a father to Pharaoh, and ruler of all his house, and of all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hurry and go to my father. Say to him, ‘Your son Joseph says to you, “God has made me ruler of all Egypt. Come to me, and do not wait.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will live in the land of Goshen, you and your children and grandchildren, your flocks and cattle, and all you have. And you will be near me.
speaker: Narrator

text: There I will take care of you, so that you and your family will not be in need. For there are still five years coming without food. By then you would have nothing.”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin see, that it is my mouth which is speaking to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must tell my father of all my greatness in Egypt, and of all you have seen. You must hurry and bring my father here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he put his arms around his brother Benjamin and cried. And Benjamin cried on his neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph kissed all his brothers and cried over them. After that his brothers talked with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news was heard in Pharaoh’s house that Joseph’s brothers had come, Pharaoh and his servants were pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers this: ‘Load your animals and go to the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take your father and your families and come to me. I will give you the best of the land of Egypt. And you will live on the fat of the land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Also say to them, ‘Take wagons from the land of Egypt for your little ones and your wives. Bring your father and come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not worry about the things that belong to you. For the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Israel did as he said. Joseph gave them wagons as Pharaoh had told him. And he gave them what they would need as they traveled.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave new clothes to each of them. But to Benjamin he gave 300 pieces of silver and five times as many clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: To his father he sent ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and things his father would need as he traveled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent his brothers away. As they left he said to them, “Do not be mad at each other on the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went out of Egypt and came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: They told him, “Joseph is still alive! He is ruler of all the land of Egypt!” Jacob’s heart almost stopped, because he did not believe them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they told him all the things that Joseph had said to them. And when he saw the wagons that Joseph had sent to carry him, the life of Jacob’s spirit returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said, “It is enough. My son Joseph is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel traveled with all he had to Beersheba. There he gave gifts to the God of his father Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke to Israel in special dreams in the night, saying, “Jacob, Jacob.” And Jacob answered, “Here I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go to Egypt. For I will make you a great nation there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will go with you to Egypt. I will bring you out again. And Joseph’s hand will close your eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob left Beersheba. The sons of Israel carried their father Jacob, their little ones and their wives in the wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took their animals and all the things they owned from the land of Canaan. And they came to Egypt, Jacob and all his children with him,
speaker: Narrator

text: his sons and grandsons, his daughters and granddaughters. He brought all his children with him to Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Reuben’s sons Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah (but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan). The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puvvah, Iob, and Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon and Jahleel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons who were born to Leah and Jacob in Paddan-aram, with his daughter Dinah. He had thirty-three sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gad were Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and their sister Serah. The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Jacob and Zilpah, the woman whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah. She gave birth to sixteen of Jacob’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jacob’s wife Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Joseph in the land of Egypt were Manasseh and Ephraim. Their mother was Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, the religious leader of On.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Jacob and Rachel, fourteen sons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan’s son was Hushim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the sons of Jacob and Bilhah, the woman whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel. There were seven sons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people who came to Egypt with Jacob, the children of his own body, were sixty-six people in all. Added to this were the wives of Jacob’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two sons were born to Joseph in Egypt. So all the people of Jacob’s family when he came to Egypt were seventy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to learn the way to Goshen. And they came to the land of Goshen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph made his wagon ready and went to Goshen to meet his father Israel. When he came to him, they put their arms around each other and cried for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel said to Joseph, “Now let me die, since I have seen your face and know that you are still alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s family, “I will go and tell Pharaoh, ‘My brothers and my father’s family have come to me from the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men are shepherds, for they have taken care of animals. They have brought their flocks and cattle and all they have.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh calls you and says, ‘What is your work?’
speaker: Narrator

text: you answer, ‘Your servants have taken care of cattle since we were young, both we and our fathers.’ Then he will let you live in the land of Goshen. For the Egyptians look down upon every shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph went to Pharaoh and said, “My father and my brothers and their flocks and cattle and all they own have come from the land of Canaan. See, they are in the land of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took five men from among his brothers, and brought them to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to his brothers, “What is your work?” So they said to Pharaoh, “Your servants are shepherds, both we and our fathers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Pharaoh, “We have come to live in the land, for there is no field with food for our flocks. The time without food is hard in the land of Canaan. So now we ask of you, let your servants live in the land of Goshen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land of Egypt is in front of you. Have your father and your brothers live in the best of the land. Let them live in the land of Goshen. And if you know any able men among them, put my cattle in their care.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph brought his father Jacob to Pharaoh. Jacob prayed that good would come to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh said to Jacob, “How old are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob answered Pharaoh, “I have traveled on this earth for 130 years. The years of my life have been few and full of sorrow, and less than the years that my fathers lived.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob prayed that good would come to Pharaoh, and went away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph made a place for his father and his brothers. He gave them a part of the land of Egypt, in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph gave food to his father and his brothers and all his father’s family, for the needs of their children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was no food in the land for the time without food was very hard. So the people in the land of both Egypt and Canaan became weak because of hunger.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph gathered all the money that was found in Egypt and Canaan for the grain they bought. And Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the money was gone from the lands of Egypt and Canaan, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, “Give us food! Why should we die in front of you? For we have no more money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said, “Give your cattle. I will give you food in trade for your cattle, because your money is gone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought their animals to Joseph. And Joseph gave them food in trade for the horses and flocks and cattle and donkeys. He fed them that year in trade for their animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When that year ended, they came to him the next year. They said, “We will not hide from my lord that our money is all gone. And the cattle belong to my lord. There is nothing left for our lord except our bodies and our lands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should we die in front of you and our lands be wasted? Buy us and our land in trade for food. We and our land will work for Pharaoh. Give us seed, so that we may live and not die, and so the land will not be wasted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh. For every Egyptian sold his field, because the time without food was hard for them. So the land became Pharaoh’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had the people move to the cities from one end of Egypt to the other, to work for Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only the land of the religious leaders he did not buy. For the religious leaders received money from Pharaoh. They lived on the money Pharaoh gave them. So they did not sell their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph said to the people, “See, today I have bought you and your land for Pharaoh. Now here is seed for you to plant in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: At gathering time, you must give a fifth part to Pharaoh. Keep the rest to have seeds for the field, and to feed yourselves and your children and those of your houses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said, “You have saved our lives! Let us find favor in the eyes of my lord. We will be Pharaoh’s servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph made it a law in the land of Egypt that Pharaoh should have the fifth part. It is a law to this day. Only the land of the religious leaders did not become Pharaoh’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in Goshen. They became richer there, and had children, and grew to a very large number.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years. So Jacob had lived 147 years in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time came for Israel to die, he called his son Joseph. He said to him, “If I have found favor in your eyes, give me your promise to be kind and faithful to me. I ask of you, do not bury me in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But let me lie down with my fathers. Carry me out of Egypt and bury me where they are buried.” And Joseph said, “I will do as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob said, “Promise me.” So Joseph gave him his promise. Then Israel bowed in worship at the head of the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Joseph was told, “See, your father is sick.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph has come to you,” Israel gathered his strength and sat up in bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob said to Joseph, “The All-powerful God showed Himself to me at Luz in the land of Canaan, and He brought good to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘See, I will give you many children. I will make you a group of nations. And I will give this land to your children and to your children’s children after you. It will belong to them forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now your two sons, who were born to you in Egypt before I came to you here, are mine. Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine, as Reuben and Simeon are.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children born to you after them will be yours. They will be called by the names of their brothers in their share of what the family is to receive.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when I came from Paddan, Rachel died by my side in the land of Canaan before we came to Ephrath. I buried her there on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel saw Joseph’s sons, he said, “Who are these?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his father, “They are my sons, whom God has given me here.” So Israel said, “Bring them to me, so I may pray that good will come to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Israel’s eyes had become weak from being old, and he could not see. So Joseph brought them near to him. And Israel kissed them and put his arms around them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel said to Joseph, “I never thought I would see your face. But see, God has let me see your children also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph took them from his knees, and bowed to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then taking Ephraim with his right hand, Joseph put him at Israel’s left side. And with his left hand he put Manasseh at Israel’s right side, placing them near him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Israel put out his right hand and laid it on the head of Ephraim, the younger son. And he put his left hand on Manasseh’s head, crossing his hands. But Manasseh was the first-born.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed that good would come to Joseph, and said, “The God with Whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked, the God Who has been my Shepherd all my life to this day,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Angel Who has set me free from all sin, bring good to the boys. May my name and the names of my fathers Abraham and Isaac live on in them. May they become a great nation on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph saw that his father laid his right hand on Ephraim’s head, he was not pleased. He took his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his father, “Not this way, my father, for this one is the first-born. Place your right hand on his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father would not, and said, “I know, my son, I know. He will become a nation also, and he also will be great. But his younger brother will be greater than he. His children and their children’s children will become many nations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed that day that good would come to them. He said, “By you Israel will pray that good will come, saying, ‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh!’” So he placed Ephraim before Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel said to Joseph, “See, I am about to die. But God will be with you. He will return you to the land of your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have given you more than your brothers. I have given you the side of the mountain that I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jacob called his sons and said, “Gather yourselves together so that I may tell you what will happen to you in the days to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather together and hear, O sons of Jacob. Listen to your father Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Reuben, you are my first-born, my power and the beginning of my strength, first in pride and first in power.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because you are as wild as water, the first place will not be yours. It is because you went to your father’s bed and made it unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Simeon and Levi are brothers. They hurt others with their swords.
speaker: Narrator

text: May my soul not have a part in their secrets, nor my shining-greatness be joined to them. Because in their anger they killed men and for no reason they hurt cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their anger will be punished, for it is bad. Their bad temper will be punished, for it is bad. I will divide them in Jacob and spread them apart in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Judah, your brothers will praise you. Your hand will be on the neck of those who hate you. Your father’s sons will bow down to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah is a young lion. Like a lion full of meat, you have become great, my son. He lies down and sleeps like a lion. And as a lion, who is willing to wake him?
speaker: Narrator

text: The right of a ruler will not leave Judah. The ruler’s special stick will not go from between his feet, until Shiloh comes. Then the people will obey Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ties his young donkey to the vine, his donkey’s young one to the best vine. He washes his clothes in wine, his coats in the blood of grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: His eyes are darker than wine. And his teeth are whiter than milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Zebulun will live beside the sea and be a safe place for ships. His land will lie beside Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Issachar is a strong donkey lying down between the loads.
speaker: Narrator

text: He saw that a resting place was good and that the land was pleasing. So he made his shoulder ready to carry loads. He let himself be a servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Dan will judge his people, as one of the families of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan will be a snake in the way, a snake in the road, that bites the horse’s heels so that the man falls off.
speaker: Narrator

text: I wait for Your saving power, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A group of soldiers will go against Gad. But he will go against them at their heels.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Asher’s food will be rich. He will give pleasing food to kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Naphtali is a female deer let loose who gives beautiful young ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Joseph is a branch with much fruit, a branch with much fruit by a well. It grows over the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men fought against him with their bows. They sent arrows toward him and made it hard for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his bow did not shake. His arms were made strong by the hands of the Powerful One of Jacob, by the name of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: by the God of your father Who helps you, and by the All-powerful Who brings good to you. He brings good from heaven above, and from the deep that lies below, and from the body of a mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: More good has come to your father than to my fathers before me, as lasting as the hills that last forever. May this good be on the head of Joseph, on the crown of him who was divided from his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Benjamin is a hungry wolf. In the morning he eats the animals he has caught. And in the evening he divides what he has taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All these are the twelve family groups of Israel. This is what their father said to them when he prayed that good would come to them. He prayed for each of them to receive the good they should have.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he told them, “I will soon be with my people who have died before me. Bury me with my fathers in the grave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the grave that is in the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre, in the land of Canaan. Abraham bought this grave and the field from Ephron the Hittite for a burying place.
speaker: Narrator

text: There they buried Abraham and his wife Sarah. There they buried Isaac and his wife Rebekah. And there I buried Leah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The field and the grave that is in it were bought from the sons of Heth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jacob finished telling his sons what to do, he lay back down on his bed and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph threw himself upon his father, and cried over him and kissed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph told his servants the doctors to make his father ready to be buried. So the doctors made Israel ready.
speaker: Narrator

text: Forty days were needed for this. For this is how much time it took for making the body ready to be buried. And the Egyptians cried for him seventy days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the days of sorrow for him were past, Joseph said to those of Pharaoh’s house, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, speak to Pharaoh, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘My father had me make a promise to him. He said, “See, I am about to die. Bury me in my grave which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan.” So let me go and bury my father. Then I will return.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh answered, “Go and bury your father as he made you promise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph went to bury his father. With him went all the servants of Pharaoh, the leaders of his house and all the important men of the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all those of the house of Joseph, and his brothers, and those of his father’s house. They left only their little ones and their flocks and cattle in the land of Goshen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wagons and men on horses went with him also. It was a very large group of people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to the grain-floor of Atad on the other side of the Jordan. There they cried with much sorrow. Joseph cried in sorrow for his father for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those who lived in the land, the Canaanites, saw the people crying in sorrow at the grain-floor of Atad, they said, “This is a great sorrow for the Egyptians.” So the place was given the name Abel-mizraim. It is on the other side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jacob’s sons did as he had told them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They carried him to the land of Canaan. They buried him in the grave of the field of Machpelah, east of Mamre, which Abraham had bought with the field from Ephron the Hittite for a burying place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt with his brothers and all who had gone with him to bury his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “It may be now that Joseph will hate us, and pay us in return for all the wrong that we did to him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sent word to Joseph, saying, “Before he died, our father told us,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You say to Joseph, “Forgive the wrong-doing of your brothers and their sin. For they did a bad thing to you.”’ Now we beg you, forgive the wrong-doing of the servants of the God of your father.” Joseph cried when they spoke to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his brothers came and fell down in front of him and said, “See, we are your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joseph said to them, “Do not be afraid. Am I in the place of God?
speaker: Narrator

text: You planned to do a bad thing to me. But God planned it for good, to make it happen that many people should be kept alive, as they are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do not be afraid. I will take care of you and your little ones.” He gave them comfort and words of kindness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph and his father’s family stayed in Egypt. And Joseph lived 110 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived long enough to see Ephraim’s grandchildren. And the sons of Manasseh’s son Machir were held on Joseph’s knees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am about to die. But God will take care of you. He will bring you from this land to the land that He promised to Abraham, to Isaac and to Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joseph made the sons of Israel promise. He said, “God will take care of you. And you will carry my bones from here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joseph died after living 110 years. They made his body ready, and he was put in a grave in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator
